name: Young Devon Accommodation
synopsis: Supported accommodation.
description:
A safe place to call home is possibly the most critical thing which young people who are in crisis might need. We are here to help young people to develop resilience; this is much harder to do without the sense of security and support that a place to call home offers. If we can stop a young person from becoming homeless we will do everything that we can to do that. But when that hasn’t worked we are committed to improving the range, quality and amount of accommodation that we can offer to young people.

One of our most profound challenges is to support young people in very chaotic situations. There is an expectation that we can help them develop a sense of stability and independence in less than a year or eighteen months even when the situations which have brought about that sense of chaos may have persisted for years or even a lifetime.

Our accommodation services promote choice and allow us to spend a longer period of time so we can support young people to successful independent living.

address.street1: Not address of accommodation - for search purposes only

accommodation.referralNotes: Please contact the Young Devon Accommodation team on 01752 698402.

name: Yardley House
synopsis: Emergency accommodation for 16 - 25 year olds
description:
Yardley House (Yardley) provides emergency accommodation, for up to three months, for 15 young men and women aged 16-25. The scheme used to be single sex but now accepts both men and women. The property is based in the Yardley area of Birmingham and is staffed 24 hours a day..

The property comprises of 6 self contained bedsits with shared bathrooms. In addition there are 9 rooms with shared bathrooms, kitchens and lounge. Also on site are an IT room, laundry and music room.

There is disabled access to part of the building.

name: YMCA Exeter Supported Accommodation
synopsis: Supported Accommodation
description:
Every year YMCA Exeter provides Supported Accommodation for over 100 young people and helps many more find accommodation that is suitable to them.

We have four stages of supported accommodation based across the city. These stages allow young people to have the level of support input that matches their needs. This can decrease or increase as needed. Moving from one stage of support to another doesn't necessarily mean moving accommodation.

In general:

* Stage 1 is based at our 31 bedroom residential centre in St David’s Hill. Support is available on site almost lal teh time and each young person has a named worker for themselves. We have a huge amount of activities and groups they can get involved in across the week and access to trips away.

* Stage 2 is generally based in larger shared houses (4 beds) where young people learn to live in smaller communities and sharing facilities. Accommodation rent levels are lower to enable people to work and still live affordably. Support is still based on site and there are regular groups and activities to get involved in.

* Stage 3 is generally based in smaller shared houses (2 beds) or self contained accommodation. Rents are purposefully kept as low as possible (usually at or close to LHA rates) to enable young people to live affordably whilst working. Stage 3 houses are in close proximity to other Stage 3 houses and Young People are encouraged and empowered to take an active part in this community and provide neighbourly support to each other. Outreach workers arrange regular meet up and are always contactable as needed.

Stage 4 is more usually in either self contained accommodation or larger shared houses where young people choose this more affordable way of living. Support is available as needed on request. Regular contact and social groups are organised and rents are kept low to enable young people to live affordably whilst working.

Young People applying must be below 30 at the point of applying to the service. There is no requirement for those already in our services who turn 30 to move on due to their age.

We can also accommodate 16-17-year-olds via a referral through Social Services.

There isn’t really a set time that young people can live at the YMCA, some stay with us for one year, others for several years as they move through our stages of accommodation before finding a permanent home of their own.

Our accommodation is specifically for young people who are coming out of homelessness and would like the support of a caring community to move forward. Some of our residents have been sleeping rough, some have been asked to leave their current home situation (or be threatened with this) and others may have been sofa surfing or living in a tent or car. 

YMCA Exeter isn’t just a place to stay though. Our Link Workers support residents during their stay at YMCA so they can develop their own potential in body, mind and spirit.

contact.name: YMCA Exeter
contact.additionalInfo: Please contact us via telephone, email or via our website at www.ymcaexeter.org.uk

accommodation.referralNotes: If you think that YMCA Exeter might be a good option for you or someone you know, then you can get in touch with  YMCA Exeter by visiting https://www.ymcaexeter.org.uk/i-need-support/find-somewhere-to-live/.

features.additionalFeatures: Various different types of accommodation are available based on the Stage of Support required.

support.supportInfo: Some Support Stages have overnight staffing, some have support on site throughout the day and others have outreach services.

name: YMCA - St Margaret's
synopsis: Semi-Supported self-Contained flats for Young People aged 18-25
description:
St Margarets is close to the city centre in Stoke, with good transport links to other parts of the City. The project has 15 spacious self-contained one bedroom flats which are partly furnished for young people age 18-25. This is a semi supported service, for up to 2 years stay. Residents also have access to shared facilities; a laundry room, a large communal lounge and a rear garden with limited parking.

*Applying for accommodation in Coventry*
Eligibility – All applicants need to have local connection with the City.
We take referrals direct from young people aged 18-25 in need of accommodation or anyone who works with them. Applicants must attend an interview to enable us to assess their support needs before an offer of accommodation can be made. If we can’t help, we will offer guidance in finding a more suitable home.

features.additionalFeatures: shared facilities; a laundry room, a large communal lounge and a rear garden with limited parking.

name: YMCA - Parkside Road
synopsis: Supported accommodation for young single homeless people aged 16-25 with support needs.
description:
40 bed space supported accommodation unit for young single homeless people aged 16-25 with support needs. 
There are also 4 bed spaces for you single pregnant women. 
Project accepts those with drug and alcohol issues, ex-offenders, and people on tags or subject to ASBOs. 
Support offered via one 2 one sessions with a dedicated support worker.
.

support.supportInfo:
* 24 hour support offered
* Key work system, with weekly meetings. Action plans with agreed outcomes, reviewed regularly
* Staff can help with CVs and job search. Counselling service, drug and alcohol project
* Compulsory support programme.

name: YMCA - Mansfield Road
synopsis: Nottinghamshire YMCA provides housing support for homeless local people (aged 16+) at the charity&rsquo;s hostels on Shakespeare Street and Peachy Street in Nottingham city centre.
description:
Our charity has 98 fully furnished room in the city centre, which feature shared kitchens and communal areas for residents. Our accommodation is staffed 24 hours a day by the YMCA Housing team, with staff members on hand at the main reception (4 Shakespeare Street) to provide support for residents, receive housing application forms and answer queries.

 

Transitional Homes
Depending on the needs of the individual, applicants may be placed in one of our transitional houses, which are based in the community across Nottingham. Whether based at our hostels or transitional shared properties, all residents have ongoing access to YMCA key worker support along their journey of regaining independence.

 

Length of stay
Please note that YMCA’s provisions are primarily geared towards providing temporary housing support for individuals in need of emergency accommodation.

Minimum tenancy: 3-6 months

Maximum tenancy: 2 years
Support and training
Whilst living at the YMCA, each resident is allocated a key worker who meets with them regularly to offer support with any issues and help plan short- and long-term goals.

Support ranges from working with residents to help sustain their tenancies and achieve independent living to guidance in developing basic living skills, managing finances and weekly budgeting, employment support and training through projects and courses. Where eligible, residents may be granted access to onsite social workers, ‘floati ng’ support worker support and/or counselling services.

We also offer refugee support and referrals to other specialist agencies. To help develop core life and social skills, our team offers a programme of onsite activities for residents ranging from creative Arts Classes to cookery skills sessions in our hostel’s fully-equipped Training Kitchen, kindly sponsored by LandAid.

accommodation.referralNotes:
Anyone applying for supported accommodation is asked to complete an application form. [Apply for YMCA housing support online](https://www.nottsymca.com/housing/application/).

Alternatively, a print version is available from the YMCA Housing reception (4 Shakespeare Street), or by contacting our housing team on 0115 837 1871.

name: YMCA - Hyde
synopsis: In England and Wales, we intensively support 228,000 young people every year, ensuring each young person we meet has an opportunity to belong, contribute and thrive.
description:
YMCA is the largest provider of safe, supported accommodation for young people in England and Wales. We offer more than 9,100 beds, which includes everything from emergency accommodation through to supported longer-term housing and youth hostels.

Our philosophy of supporting young people holistically means we provide not only a bed but also help a young person gain the training, skills and confidence to go on to lead independent lives.

YMCA provides a home to more than 18,000 people experiencing homelessness each year, making us the largest voluntary sector provider of supported housing for young people in England and Wales.

accommodation.referralNotes: To make a referral, please call 020 7186 9500.

name: YMCA - Daimler Green
synopsis: Accommodation for young people aged 18 to 25 years old
description:
Daimler Green is situated in Radford on the Daimler Green housing estate, just 2 miles from the City centre. It offers 24 units of self-contained furnished accommodation for young people aged 18 to 25 years old, who would otherwise be homeless. Staff are onsite 24 hours a day 7 days a week to provide support. This is short stay accommodation (for up to 3 months stay) and is made up of two blocks of one bedroom flats.

**Applying for YMCA accommodation in Coventry**
Eligibility – All applicants need to have local connection with the City.
We take referrals direct from young people aged 18-25 in need of accommodation or anyone who works with them. Applicants must attend an interview to enable us to assess their support needs before an offer of accommodation can be made. If we can’t help, we will offer guidance in finding a more suitable home.

support.supportInfo: Staff are onsite 24 hours a day 7 days a week to provide support.

name: Woodward Court
synopsis: Woodward court is used by Manchester City Council to assist homeless users with low-medium support needs.
description:
Woodward Court accepts all-adult homeless households (from 16+), mixed and same sex couples and groups.

We offer disabled facilities - there are two flats which are accessible to wheelchair users and three flats which are adapted to mobility standards. There are lifts to all floors. We also offer fast track equipment and adaptation assessments.

We accept visitors accompanied by a resident and overnight guests are allowed three times a week.

address.publicTransportInfo: Buses 76 and 77 from city centre to Butler Street. The bus stop is 2-3 mins walk from Woodward Court.

contact.additionalInfo: Details given here are the contact details for the Manchester City Council referral team.

accommodation.referralNotes:
Woodward Court can only accept referrals from the Manchester City Council homeless assessment team and other Manchester City Council tun temporary accommodation units. Referral can be arranged by telephone (24 hours) or in writing. Application forms are completed by the referral agency. An assessment is required, as well as proof of ID, National Insurance number and income information.

The referral contact details are: 

Manchester City Council,
Customer Service Centre,
Town Hall Extension,
Mount Street,
Manchester M2 5DB

Telephone: 0161 234 4692 or email aasdutyofficer@manchester.gov.uk
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: £7.56 - £12.32 per week is required from residents in receipt of benefits.

support.supportInfo: Woodward Court has 14 full time staff and 24 hour cover. It has a keyworker system with an average of 6 residents per worker. Staff offer housing related support.

name: Wilson Carlile house
synopsis: 38 Bed homeless accommodation for Males aged 18 - 65 with ex offenders at Risk of offending
description:
We support customers to manage and sustain tenancies secure the services and support required including Drugs Alcohol & Mental Health Improve health & Wellbeing.

All customers will work towards work skills Education training & voluntary work, with the support of an allocated support worker who will support you with your needs.  We aim to reduce social isolation and help move on into independent living.  Support is offered to all customers however we require some commitment from our customers to be ready to make positive changes to their lifestyle, improving employability skills, improving Health & Wellbeing and reduce social isolation

features.additionalFeatures: Bedding is issued at Moving in stage and then the customer will look after it by using the communal washing facilities.  Meals are not provided however we have a large communal kitchen

support.supportInfo: Wilson Carlile House is staffed 24 /7  The staff team consists of 4 support workers 2 Project assistants and security during the night

name: Wilson Carlile House
synopsis: We are a homeless hostel for men aged 18 - 65, who are ex-offenders and may have complex needs including substance misuse/use and mental health.
description:
We offer fully furnished single rooms, with washbasins. Our customers are expected to live with us for up to 6 months during this time they will be given the opportunity to receive help with Drug/Alcohol misuse receive support around Mental Health from outside agencies.  Work with a support worker working towards independent living through engaging in Training Education voluntary work and working towards employment,  We offer in house training, we have a computer suite large garden large communal kitchen & Lounge area.  Our emphasis is on Move on to independent living and engaging in Training Education Voluntary work working towards employment.  All this is done by receiving 121 support from an allocated support worker 

.

accommodation.referralNotes: We operate a referral process from agencies that our customers are working with, as well as taking self referrals. For referrals, please telephone 0161 273 3574, write or call in daily, 24 hours a day. We require a psychiatric report where applicable, as well as proof of ID and NI number at assessment.

support.supportInfo: Each customer is assigned a support worker to develop a tailored support plan. Our staff work closely with probation, police, employment agencies, drugs and alcohol agencies, local colleges, local voluntary agencies and other agencies to assist our clients with their support needs. &#10;&#10;Our support covers: life skills such as &lsquo;shopping on a budget&rsquo; sessions; a regular programme of social activities to develop customer involvement and build self-esteem;&#10;helping to identify move on accommodation by liaising with local housing associations and private landlords.

name: Willow Cottage
synopsis: Supported accommodation for people with enduring mental health needs.
description: Willow Cottage is a supported living service providing short-term accommodation and support (for up to two years) for people with enduring mental health needs. We provide a safe environment where tenants address their mental health problems, consider their options and fulfil their potential.

accommodation.referralNotes: For more information or to make a referral or self referral, please contact us.

name: Wilbraham Road
synopsis: Supported accommodation for people with severe and enduring mental health needs.
description: Wilbraham Road provides supported accommodation for adults with severe and enduring mental health needs, to help them move through their recovery journey in a safe and supportive environment. Wilbraham Road helps its residents to develop the skills they need to live independently.

accommodation.referralNotes: For more information or to make a referral or self referral, please contact us.

name: Westgate – Supported Accommodation, Burnley
synopsis: Westgate is a generic service for young single people aged 16-25 who require housing-related support to enable them to become independent in the community.
description: Westgate consists of 6 self-contained flats that are furnished to a very high standard. Tenants staying at the project have a Resettlement Worker who works on a one-to-one basis to help them develop their independent living skills and address their individual support needs.

accommodation.referralNotes: For further information on this project or to make a referral please call or email us for a referral form.

support.supportInfo:
At the move-in stage, the allocated Resettlement Worker will complete an induction programme with each new client. Following this, they will arrange an appointment with the client to agree upon an initial support plan. The information from the initial support plan will form the basis for the development of a full support/action plan. The support/action plan will be devised and agreed with the client, Resettlement Worker and any other agencies that the clients would like to be involved.

On-premises support that can be offered at Westgate, includes:

Help accessing and maintaining suitable long-term accommodation.
Advice on housing rights and responsibilities.
Help accessing specialist agencies around mental health issues.
Help accessing specialist services around substance/alcohol issues.
Help with applying for benefits, grants and loans.
Help with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts.
Help filling in forms (i.e. Welfare Benefits).
Support accessing specialist agencies and support services.
Support in accessing employment, voluntary work opportunities, training and education.
Help building self-confidence.
Support to develop shared living skills.

name: Westcliffe Supported Housing
synopsis: Drug and alcohol detoxification.
description: Westcliffe House is a 21-bed supported housing service offering accommodation to those who wish to remain abstinent from alcohol and/or drugs.

accommodation.referralNotes: For more information or to make a referral or self referral, please contact us.

name: Wellfield
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide low level support accommodation to 6 people aged 18 and upwards. The length of stay is determined by Petrus.
* To support the mental health and or drug/alcohol misuse issues.
* To build and develop long term independent living skills for move on to independent accommodation or longer term supported accommodation.
* Each resident has individual support plans and key work sessions tailored to their needs to enable them to reach their goals and aspirations.
* Residents are supported to manage their own flat and help with budgeting skills and basic life skills.
* Residents are encouraged to attend joint planning about the bigger picture of Petrus and the opportunity to meet other service users within Petrus projects.

The accommodation comprises self-contained flats.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Vulnerable Adult Supported Housing Service - Handsworth Wood Road
synopsis: Our Vulnerable Adult Supported Housing Service is accommodation that is managed by Birmingham Mind and owned by one of three partner Housing Associations
description:
Supported Housing offers support on an appointment basis between 9am – 9pm, 7 days a week, staff are not based on site.

Supported Housing is where we offer you a flat or house share with appropriate support.  How much support and what type of support is dependant on your needs but the aim of the service is to help a person to maintain a tenancy, identify their strengths and goals, develop increased self-esteem, self-worth and confidence, and to integrate into their local community.

Our Supported Housing service is funded by Birmingham City Council, Vulnerable Adults Service.

The service is delivered in partnership with the Longhurst Group and R&J Support.




Costs
The support is paid for by Birmingham City Council Vulnerable Adults Service and the rent is either paid by the person themselves or possibly covered by Housing Benefit. There is also a small service charge for services not covered by Housing Benefit. Eg communal heating and lighting. It is also possible to use Direct Payments to pay for your support.

Our Properties
We have a range of properties from shared homes to self-contained flats. Most of the accommodation is furnished with carpets, cooker, fridge/freezer and a single bed. Some of our projects are gender or ethnic specific (please see below for more details). Four properties are owned by Birmingham Mind and the rest are owned by Housing Associations, which we manage on their behalf and provide support for.

accommodation.referralNotes:
Applications can be made by individuals, professional services, statuary agencies or family members.
Applications can made via:  
Our Helpline call 0121 262 3555  
Download and email our Referral Form directly to our Referral Team.

https://birminghammind.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/VAS-referral-form.pdf


VAS_Referrals@birminghammind.org


Criteria
* Have a mental health condition
* Age 18 +
'* You need to live in or have a local connection with Birmingham (Family, support networks or GP etc)

We prioritise applications from hospital patients and those who currently reside in full time residential care.

features.additionalFeatures: In Handsworth Wood this property has 3 single self contained flats and a communal garden. The property is owned by Birmingham Mind.

support.supportInfo:
The support from our dedicated team is underpinned by the key features of recovery; hope, respect, control and personal growth. We use person centred planning tools to help identify with individuals what support they want in order to achieve their ambitions and goals. The support can include:

* Health and wellbeing support
* Developing social networks
* Accessing community facilities i.e. leisure, work and education
* Enhancing people’s confidence
* Help with skills needed to maintain a tenancy (paperwork, budgeting, environment, health and safety)
* Emotional support
* People are encouraged to be actively involved in designing their support package,  the running of each service and overall development of the Charity.

People receiving a service will be offered a Lead Worker. Lead Worker Support is available between 9.00am and 9.00pm, seven days a week. It is expected that most people will use the service for no more than 2 years although we recognise that some people may need longer.

name: Victoria House
synopsis: Victoria House helps single homeless people and rough sleepers with support needs with a Manchester connection and an active desire to participate in a programme of support.
description:
The minimum age accepted is 18 and there is no maximum age.

Visitors are allowed between 10am and 11pm, no under 16s or overnight guests.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referral is accepted from 'named agencies only'. Please write or telephone 0161 231 9400, Mon - Fri, 9am - 5pm. There is an application form to be completed by the referral agency. We require proof of ID and reports from supporting agencies where relevant. Other supporting agencies are required to attend the interview.

support.supportInfo:
There are 7 full time staff members with 24 hour cover. There is a compulsory keywork system in place with weekly meetings,

A work club and ESOL course are available. Residents must participate in the support programme.

name: Ullet Road
synopsis: 12 beds of supported accommodation for males over 16 who have no access to settled accommodation.
description: The accommodation is also shared across Lister and Ullet Road and consists of 26 mainstream rooms and two ring fenced bedrooms with communal and shared bathroom facilities, shared kitchen and laundry facilities, and shared communal lounges.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via https://liverpool.gov.uk/housing/homeless-or-at-risk/

features.additionalFeatures:
ACTIVITIES ON OFFER -
 
Activities currently on offer at Ullet Road & Lister Road include: 
Cooking on a Budget Classes,
Drama Group,
Men’s Health & Wellbeing Groups,
ICT Workshops,
Art Group,
Cinema/Movie Nights,
Breakfast Clubs,
Sunday Dinner Clubs,
Bicycle Maintenance Workshops,
Football,
Gardening Projects,
Pool Table

support.supportInfo:
On being accepted into the Support Service residents will be introduced and allocated to a member of our Support Team who will become their Key Worker. All residents will also be allocated a Secondary Key Worker who will provide support for them if their initial allocated Key Worker is unavailable. All residents are required to engage with Support Services as part of their license agreement and the support offered to them will be tailored to meet and address their own individual support needs.

We have a full time Resettlement Worker who will work alongside the support team and is also actively involved in all forms of resettlement for each individual. We currently have several professional training providers running educational programmes through external providers.

name: Transitions Housing Solutions CIC
synopsis: Transitions Housing Solutions (CIC) provides low- medium level tailored support in fully furnished, modern housing, with specialist provisions with 24/7 staffing for higher needs.
description:
We will offer a safe environment to our residents. We will support, nurture and empower all our residents towards a productive, independent life. We understand the importance of a secure, comfortable home where residents can begin their recovery journey and rebuild their lives. We pride ourselves on offering our residents all of this and so much more. We pledge to provide safe, secure, modern furnished accommodation with low-medium level key support as standard, with the flexibility of higher needs supported living provisions too.

We have the following projects: 

Support living - Rejuvenation project (was 1-1 or 2-1) – Currently in Mansfield & Nottingham.

The Rejuvenation project’s function is to provide a person centred and therapeutic practice led support and care service for adults with a range of support and care needs that include, mental health, learning difficulties and autism, in a range of accommodation such as Self-contained flats Bungalows and Shared living depending on the residents needs and wants. Our service aims to promote independency and enablement with competent and qualified staff available 24 hours a day, 1-1, 2-1, 3-1 or 4-1 etc.

Supported Accommodation - Positive Change Project (HMO’s) City & County 

Our Positive Change Project provides supported accommodation for adults with low-medium housing related support needs. For single adults that have been or are currently homeless, rough sleeping or vulnerably housed with issues related to offending behaviour, substance misuse, mental health etc.

6 Months support/6 Months Funded placements towards employability – Pathways Project Nottingham Only 

Our Pathways Project’s objective is to provide a home and a bespoke support service for vulnerable adults ready to progress and make meaningful changes in their lives to gain employment.

name: The Springs
synopsis: The Springs provides supported housing for single men and women with low support needs who are willing to engage in education, training, paid or voluntary work.
description:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE
* We appreciate what an uncertain and worrying time this is for our customers across the country. 
* We are monitoring Government advice and as a result have introduced a number of changes to our services. This is to ensure we minimise risks to the health and safety of our customers and staff whilst also trying to continue to deliver our services to you.
* All key information on how our services are operating is available on our [Q&A webpage](https://www.riverside.org.uk/coronavirus-information-for-customers/)
* Added 26 March 2020


The Springs provides supported housing for single men and women with low support needs who are willing to engage in education, training, paid or voluntary work.

Individual support is provided to prepare you to move on to independent living and to help meet your ambitions and goals.


**You’ll find:**
* Self-contained flats with single bedrooms and shared bathroom and kitchen facilities
* Meeting and support room for group workshops, training courses and residents’ meetings
* Individual, tailored support plans developed with you and your Support Worker
* Support from external agencies to identify any training and employment opportunities
* A resettlement worker to work with you and your Support Worker to develop a move-on plan

**How it works:**
All referrals are through the Inform. All referrals will be need and risk assessed and interviewed, and agreed by the Springs panel which means every fortnight.

You will be aged 18-65, homeless with low support needs and have a local connection to the Cambridgeshire area. You must be willing to engage in employment, education or training contracts.

**Getting the most out of our service:**
* Opportunity to engage with training or conferences, and to become a ‘customer representative’ for Riverside and participate in social opportunities
* Resettlement funding available to help buy essential household items when you move on to your new home
* Accommodation at the Springs is conditional and everyone must meet the engagement contract during their stay. Everyone is expected to engage in education, training or employment opportunities for a minimum of 14 hours a week. 

When entering the service your support worker will arrange an appointment for you to meet with partner agencies. They will assist you in completing the goals identified in your personal development plan. Your support worker will also work with you to develop your support plan, incorporating objectives and actions which will contribute to you meeting the engagement contract.

**Why we are different:**
We give personalised support to help you pursue your aspirations in education, training and employment. We’ll also prepare you to become tenancy ready, to help you move on confidently to independent living.

address.publicTransportInfo: There is a bus stop (Histon Road Corner) for the Citi 8 service within 100 metres of The Springs.

contact.name: Zak Anderson
contact.additionalInfo: Zak Anderson is the support worker in the Springs. He is available 09:00 - 17:00 weekdays.

accommodation.referralNotes:
The service operates on a referral basis only, and provided you meet the eligibility criteria you will be asked to complete the required documentation at the point of referral. 

On completion of the referral documentation you will be invited for an interview where a member of the support team will complete Needs and Risk assessment.

The gross rent is &pound; 182.21 per week and this is housing benefit eligible. There is a service charge which varies.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Meals are not provided however there is a fare share delivery of 100kg of food each week on Thursdays. There is also an involvement budget that funds social/food related activities (e.g BBQ).

features.additionalFeatures: The Springs provides bedding on arrival however there is no clean bedding service.

support.supportInfo:
The Springs provides supported housing for those with low support needs who are willing to engage in education, training, paid or voluntary work.

Move on is a priority, and Riverside employs a specialist support worker who will work with you and your support worker to identify suitable move on accommodation, and assist you towards greater independence. You are expected to attend the pre tenancy workshops which will prepare you for moving into, and managing a permanent tenancy.

name: The Pleasance Lifehouse
synopsis: We offer a safe, supportive environment for individuals, helping them make positive choices about their current circumstances.
description: The Pleasance is a Rapid Access Accommodation service and a key part in the City of Edinburgh approach to reducing rough sleeping and towards reducing homelessness.  Residents are referred from street based agencies and stay with us until appropriate temporary accommodation and support is identified and accessed.

accommodation.referralNotes:
All referrals come from **Streetwork**. Their team can be contacted on at 18 South Bridge, Edinburgh, EH1 1LL, and on 0808 178 2323.

Users need to be able to access Housing benefit, and have a right to support from the City of Edinburgh Council.

We serve both couples and individuals. There is no personal charge for staying at The Pleasance.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Breakfast is included in the service, and other food is made available from a range of donors for use in the kitchens.

name: The Orchard Lifehouse
synopsis: Provision of 41 beds (38 men and 3 women) for single people who are homeless, with low support needs, with signposting to specialist support services.

features.additionalFeatures: Self Catering

name: The Old Vicarage
synopsis: Accomodation for adults with mental health difficulties
description: The scheme provides supported accommodation, access to a range of education, training and employment opportunities and community health services to enable residents to take the next steps towards independent living.

contact.name: The Old Vicarage
contact.additionalInfo: The scheme provides supported accommodation, access to a range of education, training and employment opportunities and community health services to enable residents to take the next steps towards independent living.

accommodation.referralNotes: Residents are referred to the scheme through other support agencies.

features.additionalFeatures: There are seven self-contained flats with a bathroom, kitchen, bedroom and living room.

support.supportInfo:
Each resident is allocated a support worker to offer emotional support, help with applying for benefits, and encourage service users to maximise their independence and achieve a better quality of life.

They also receive support to help them maintain and develop independent living skills, including food preparation and attending to personal care, supporting integration in the local community and promoting opportunities for educational, employment and social activities.

name: The Limes
synopsis: The Limes provides supported housing for 26 young men aged 16 - 30.
description: This information is currently under verification.

accommodation.referralNotes:
The agreed referral routes are: Sunrise Project, City Centre Project, Refugee Action and other agencies.

Please contact Shane for further information on 0161 224 5883 or shanem@chapterone.org.uk or limes@chapter1.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
The Limes provides education and training to homeless and marginalised people as well as the local community on a weekly basis. 

We offer various activities and courses to our residents, such as sport leadership training, healthy living, pre-tenancy training, vegetable growing etc.

support.supportInfo:
The project is staffed from 8am until midnight every day. An emergency service is provided by a sleep-in member of staff and an on-call service, as well as a waking Night Concierge.

Service Users will normally stay at our project for a period of two years before moving on to independent living.

An annexe building at the rear with six furnished rooms is part of a new initiative between Manchester City Council and Chapter 1 The Limes, housing young rough sleepers, who receive intensive and holistic housing-related support.

name: The Elms
synopsis: The Elms provides a Tier 1 24 hour temporary accommodation and support service to vulnerable people aged 16+, who have no immediate access to settled accommodation.
description:
We offer short term accommodation and support with a clear emphasis on enabling people to develop skills to live independently within the community. The maximum length of stay is 6 months.

All flats are fully furnished including cooker, fridge and washing machine. Additionally, all the flats are equipped with crockery, pans, cooking utensils and bedding along with a welcome pack for all new residents. Free Wi-Fi is provided around the building and there is a rear garden available for residents’ use.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures: We offer in-house support with independent living skills and signposting for training.

name: The Booth Centre
synopsis: The Booth Centre is a 43 Bed Lifehouse for those facing homelessness in Southampton. We support residents facing numerous issues to get back onto their feet and move on to their own accommodation.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referral can be made through the Street Homeless Prevention Team via the Two Saints Day Centre or through the Gateway Housing Panel managed by Homegroup

name: Temporary Accommodation
synopsis: Temporary Accommodation is for those who are experiencing homelessness and who are due interim housing by the Council.
description: Anyone who is homeless or threatened with homelessness should present at Stockport Homes to see a Housing Officer.

name: Tekoa House
synopsis: Tekoa house is a large hostel for homeless men and women - both with and without an offending background and those at risk of offending.

accommodation.referralNotes: Exclusions apply to Tekoa House, please contact our referrals team for more information: referrals@langleyhousetrust.org

support.supportInfo: We offer a range of activities including links to voluntary work and access to the Langley Academy.

name: Tabor House
synopsis: Emergency Bed Accommodation
description:
Tabor House provides a safe and welcoming environment for guests, with three meals per day, showers, and laundry facilities all included. Some guests arrive with nothing but the clothes they’re wearing so we source everything they need, and support them as they re-build their self-esteem.

With a very small staff team and an army of dedicated volunteers, which has now grown to around 50 people, we have been able to help over 100 rough sleepers through interventions, signposting and support. Everything centres around our strength-based mentoring, which helps guests identify what they love and can do, rather than focusing on their problems or weaknesses.

We accompany and support guests in areas such as identity documents or re-engaging with medical services and the Department for Work and Pensions. We also help establish connections with family and friends, if this is deemed part of their trauma recovery. We also help our guests find permanent accommodation and, more often than not, paid employment with a 75% success rate.

We can have nine guests staying at Tabor House and the team will ensure that guests will have a place to move on to at the end of their stay

Tabor House supports guests of any gender over the age of 25 who are referred by partner organisations..

accommodation.referralNotes:
If you work for an organisation working to reduce homelessness, please contact us during office hours by calling on 0121 647 5106 or emailing sharonfear@fatherhudsons.org.uk.

**For an individual being referred**

Once referred to us, the team at Tabor House will process your application and you will then be made welcome when a bed is available. Please note, there is waiting list so a bed on the same night cannot be guaranteed.

One of the benefits of Tabor House, however, is that it does not require guests to have recourse to public funds, making it more accessible for a wider variety of people who need it.

Download a referral form [here](https://www.taborliving.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Tabor-House-guest-referral-form-003.docx)

support.supportInfo:
Once at Tabor House, a review is conducted to better understand the challenges of moving our guests into a more permanent living situation. This might include anything from visa status and identity documents, through to substance misuse and language barriers.

Each guest is supported by our trained staff team and volunteers, helping them to overcome these challenges, both big and small. They also have a Volunteer Mentor, who sees them on a weekly basis, including three months after they leave Tabor House.

We work with partner agencies to host workshops and training in areas such as English language, employability skills, and core life skills such as cooking.

Across Tabor Living, we are committed to do everything that we can to enable each of our guests to take control of their lives and take steps towards securing independent living accommodation and employment. We provide guests with a hand-up not a hand-out.

Tabor House is the only accommodation project in the city to take a strength-based approach to support. This means that our mentors and volunteers seek to find our guests’ personal skills and passions, and empower them to make positive steps in their lives. Rather than focus on all of the things they think they can’t do as a result of experiencing homelessness.

Both our Volunteer Mentors and Shift Leaders have been trained by national homelessness charity, the Mayday Trust, to use this innovative approach and we’ve since fantastic and positive results since day one.

name: Sussex Nightstop
synopsis: Sussex Nightstop is a local homeless charity that has worked in the Brighton & Hove area for over ten years now. We provide short, overnight stays in volunteer host homes for young people aged 16-25.
description:
Sussex Nightstop is a Brighton & Hove homeless charity that prevents rough-sleeping by setting up short stays in the homes of volunteer hosts who have a spare room to offer. We are one of over 30 accredited Nightstop services in operation across the UK; offering free, short-stay, emergency accommodation in warm, welcoming, family homes.

Our Nightstop guests are either at risk of rough-sleeping, have had a short experience of rough-sleeping or find themselves needing to use other potentially unsafe sleeping arrangements, such as sofa-surfing. At a point of crisis and vulnerability, guests are often trying to maintain positive investments in their life such as work, study or training.  

Nightstop works with people who have a low or medium level and who otherwise meet our service thresholds. We focus our efforts where we think we can make the most difference with the resource we have available. Currently, we are working with young people age 16-25 years only.

The negative effects of rough-sleeping and sofa-surfing are profound. By providing safe accommodation at the earliest point, our Nightstop service provides people with the best opportunity to work on their housing plan. Working together with our local housing advice partners, our goal is that Nightstop guests move from our service into a safe, longer-term place they can call home.

Our volunteer host households are based in Brighton & Hove and outlying areas in Sussex that are easily accessible by a short journey on public transport. They are recruited, screened, trained and supported by us to carry out their role in a safe and effective way. Our hosts provide a safe private room, a hot meal, access to washing facilities and a listening ear if needed. Our service provides a very practical way that people can volunteer in support of reducing homelessness.

Accessing our service is through our approved referral agencies only. These are currently YMCA DLG Housing Advice and Brighton & Hove City Council Children’s Services.  We don’t accept self-referrals, but we welcome enquiries about our service.

address.publicTransportInfo: Co-located with Brighton & Hove YMCA Youth Advice Centre (YAC) in the centre of Brighton, which is accessible by bus and train.

accommodation.referralNotes:
If you are aged 16-25 years contact YMCA Youth Advice Centre (YAC). YAC are continuing to take referrals and offer support and advice remotely by phone and online. There are currently no face-to-face appointments. To get advice and support from YAC housing advice:
Phone 01273 624 432 or email yacbrightonhousingadvice@ymcadlg.org

If you are at risk of homelessness, for example because accommodation with friends and family is ending, please contact housing early intervention team:

Phone 01273 294 400 or email earlyintervention@brighton-hove.gov.uk

features.additionalFeatures: Nightstop hosts always offer a warm welcome.

support.supportInfo: Providing a service that is safe for our guests and volunteers and staff is our number one priority. Our operations manager and on-call volunteers provide a point of contact for our volunteer hosts and guests outside of office hours. Through guidance and reassurance they are there to facilitate safe guest placements that have been fully risk-assessed and set up by Nightstop staff.

name: Supported Housing
synopsis: Supported Housing & Floating Support
description:
We are a leading provider of supported housing in Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire. We make a difference to the lives of over 600 people living in our homes and in partnership with other supported living providers.

We are committed to providing homes and a high standard of care for people experiencing mental ill-health, physical or learning disabilities. Our aim is to enable our customers to lead as independent a life as they possibly can.

Some of our supported housing is self-contained, while other accommodation is in shared housing.

Our service philosophy is to promote equality, independence and empowerment underpinned by principles of respect, dignity and choice, delivered through individual lifestyle agreements

address.street1: Supported Housing Team, Aldwyck Housing Group

accommodation.referralNotes: Please visit https://www.aldwyck.co.uk/download.cfm?doc=docm93jijm4n1082.pdf&ver=2001 to download an application form and return the form to our postal or email address.

name: Streetlife Night Shelter
synopsis: Our Shelter on Church Street is warm, safe and friendly. Opens at  19:00 every night
description:
For 16 - 26 year olds, The Shelter has eight small individual bedrooms and there are two workers on duty each night.

You can have a shower and wash your clothes. The Shelter
opens every night at 7pm and closes at 9am each morning and our contact number is 01253 291038.

You can also telephone The Base on 01253 294477 – staff are
available from 9am. You can ask for an appointment to
get one-to-one support from workers. Our workers can
help you get the support you need around housing, health,
benefits, education, training, employment and much more.

address.publicTransportInfo: Opposite the Winter Gardens in St Johns Square

name: Stop Start Go (SSG)
synopsis: SSG is a temporary accommodation that places emphasis on what is effective and sustainable when finding secure accommodation.
description:
The service offers a supported aspect as well as a short-term accommodation arrangement for working people that have become homeless. Early intervention is crucial and Passion is at the heart if everything SSG do. 

The accommodation offers 12 rooms and has a supported aspect for those with low-to-medium support needs and also 3 rooms with service for those that are working but have either been homeless or threatened with homelessness. 

The hostel aims to place working residents into private accommodation within 4-6 weeks.

accommodation.referralNotes: referral's through Booth Centre

support.supportInfo: Will provide support for substance misuse, mental health.

name: Stoke-on-Trent Churches Community Night Shelter
synopsis: Stoke-on-Trent Churches Community Night Shelter
description:
Stoke-on-Trent Churches Community Night Shelter is working to provide a safe night’s rest to street homeless individuals within Stoke-on-Trent. 

We are open 3 nights a week (Friday-Sunday) between December and March. We have 10 beds available for our guests as well as kitchen and shower facilities.

name: Statham House
synopsis: Statham House offers 24-hour support to young people aged 16 to 17 in the Rochdale area who are leaving care, as well as taking referrals from out of the borough if we have vacancies.
description:
The service is designed to support and empower young people to improve their health, well being and self esteem. This enables young people to break damaging patterns of thinking and behaviour, take more control of their lives and move towards positive futures.
We provide young people with good quality accommodation in one of 9 one bedroom flats.

name: Start Over Shelter
synopsis: Emergency Accommodation.
description: As part of our commitment to improving the standards of accommodation available for homeless people, Signposts acquired a new building which provides modern and comfortable facilities to those in need of emergency accommodation. This is available for single homeless people, of any gender, aged 21 and over.

accommodation.referralNotes: Apply for temporary supported housing by completing this application form - https://www.signpostsso.org/application-form.

name: Stanley Lodge
synopsis: Supported accommodation
description:
There are 14 self contained studio flats and this property was refurbished in 2012 and enables residents to access affordable housing with a greater level of independence.

As the accommodation provided at Stanley Lodge is affordable we prioritise this to applicants who are working. There are no staff on this site and support is arranged by appointment with support staff.

name: St. Paul’s House
synopsis: Hostel for young women
description:
St. Paul’s House is a purpose built accommodation for single women; single parents aged 16 or over with babies and also has three family rooms available. It is situated within walking distance of the Commercial Road and Palmerston Road.

The house is staffed 24 hours per day all year round.

All clients have access to the communal kitchens, lounge, dining room, laundry facilities and garden.

We are able to support:
* Homeless people with support needs. 
* Single Parents with children up to the age of 5 years.
* Stable couple with child.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you are in need of support and housing and meet the criteria for our accommodation, then please contact Portsmouth City Council Housing Options Team by telephoning 023 9283 4989, or email them at   housing.options@portsmouthcc.gov.uk or you can visit them at the Civic Offices, Guildhall Square, Portsmouth

name: St. Anne's Hostel
synopsis: St. Anne&#39;s is a hostel for homeless men 25 years old and over plus their canine companions.  They take referrals 24 hours a day, 365 days a year
description: The have space for 37 residents.  Each resident has his own room and they have shared toilet and shower facilities.  They also have learning, TV and dining rooms.  They canine residents are allowed to stay in their owners' rooms

accommodation.referralNotes:
Download St Anne's referral form link:-
https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.stannesbirmingham.org.uk%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2017%2F08%2FSt-Annes-referral-form-1.docx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK

support.supportInfo: Support worker who will work with individuals to reach personal goals and ultimately move on into independent living.

name: St Thomas Fund (CGL)
synopsis: Residential drug and alcohol service.
description:
St Thomas Fund is a residential rehabilitation service based in Brighton and Hove that offers a safe place for adults wanting to become free of drugs and alcohol, and make positive steps towards recovery.

It is a free service for adults over the age of 18 with a local connection to Brighton and Hove; places are agreed with all parties following referral and assessment.

Most residents have a history of rough sleeping, drug and alcohol-related offending and/or other difficulties linked to their drug and alcohol use. We also work with people who have experience of complex mental and physical health needs alongside their substance misuse issues.

The service operates over three houses and can support up to 21 residents over the 3 sites.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals are via [Pavilions](http://www.pavilions.org.uk/services/treatment-recovery-options/) community drug and alcohol service.

support.supportInfo: The service operates over three houses and can support up to 21 residents over the 3 sites:&#10;&#10;STAGE 1&#10;&#10;The first &lsquo;stage&rsquo; is based at Cromwell Road. This has places for seven residents and is staffed at all times. Cromwell Road offers detoxification support to residents who need it, in partnership with drug and alcohol support services in Brighton and Hove. Some residents do not require detoxification but remain at Cromwell Road in order to stabilise and become accustomed to the structure of residential treatment.&#10;&#10;Residents are often at various stages of the detoxification and recovery process, and join the CBT-based group-work programme as well as engaging with one-to-one support. Residents are supported to reflect on and address the reasons behind their drug and alcohol use, as well as engaging with other recovery activities including creative groups, gardening and literacy support. Residents stay at Cromwell Road for around 3 months, although this is dependent on their need and progress against their support plans.&#10;&#10;STAGE 2&#10;&#10;The second stage is based at Arch House in Hove, where up to 8 residents participate in workshops and completing assignments focussing on relapse prevention, anger management, and social interaction and integration skills. Services users at Arch House are moving towards a greater degree of independence, and as such Arch is staffed during office hours. Residents can access support from Cromwell Road staff team if needed 24/7.&#10;&#10;Residents are encouraged to engage with volunteering, peer mentoring, training and education opportunities as part of the programme of recovery, explored alongside move-on accommodation options. Typically service users remain at Arch House for 4 to 6 months. &#10;&#10;STAGE 3&#10;&#10;The third stage is based at &lsquo;Star House&rsquo; in Portslade: this is the St Thomas Fund &lsquo;move-on house&rsquo;. This third stage supports residents to become fully prepared for independent living and re-engagement with the community.&#10;&#10;Service users here have largely finished the main recovery programme, and are in full time voluntary work and/or part time employment. Residents can remain here for up to two years, dependent on their needs.&#10;&#10;The service aims to reduce:&#10;&#10;* The levels of substance misuse and harm caused by * &#10;* Drugs and alcohol&#10;* Offending behaviour&#10;* Anti-social behaviour&#10;* Numbers of people rough sleeping&#10;* Drug and alcohol related deaths&#10;* Drug and alcohol related domestic violence with both perpetrators and survivors&#10;&#10;and increase:&#10;* Referrals into work and training placements&#10;* The numbers of people living in stable accommodation and entering employment, education and training

name: St Petrock's FairLets service
description:
Our FairLets service helps clients overcome barriers in accessing suitable private rented accommodation in Exeter and the surrounding area.  

The service helps match homeless/vulnerably housed clients with low-support needs, who are referred to us from St Petrock's homelessness services, Exeter City Council and partnership agencies, with trusted landlords in the private rented sector.    It assists tenants with all practical aspects involved in setting up tenancies and moving in, and provides wrap-around support to both landlords and clients to ensure tenancies are successfully maintained.

name: St Patrick’s Hostel
synopsis: Emergency hostel for people who are homeless.
description:
St Patrick’s in Hove, provides housing and support to single homeless people including those with a history of substance misuse, offending, or those who have been affected by mental health problems, in Brighton.

* 29 fully furnished rooms over three floors.
* Shared kitchens and bathrooms.
* Four rough sleeper pods providing emergency accommodation.
* Spaces for dogs (limited number).
* Tailored one-to-one support including signposting to partner agencies to access additional services.
* IT groups and a garden where people can grow and maintain flowers and shrubs.
* Weekly games night.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals must be made via Brighton and Hove Council Supported [Living Panel](https://www.brighton-hove.gov.uk/content/social-care/support-live-home/supported-living).

support.supportInfo:
Customers are signposted to local agencies, including alcohol and substance misuse services, medical professionals, probation services, domestic violence support and community groups including LGBT and ethnic minority groups.

To make progress through the homeless pathway, customers are supported to further their education and encouraged to volunteer to prepare them for independent living and work opportunities.

name: St George’s
synopsis: Supported accommodation
description: St George’s deliver support to 17 young people. Accommodation is all self-contained and support enables young people to achieve a greater level of independence.

name: St George's Crypt Emergency Accommodation
synopsis: Emergency accommodation for rough sleepers
description:
Positioned in the heart of Leeds, St George's Crypt provides an award winning 24/7 emergency accommodation for men and women who are homeless or rough sleeping. Not just about rehousing. St George's Crypt seeks to promote health and well being, through joint working with other agencies offering specialist support that residents are able to have access to. Through assessments the residents have a tailored support plan to help the resident achieve positive goals to achieve independent living.

We currently have 15 beds available - 12 beds are available through referral from Housing Options, and 3 beds through referral from the NHS HHIT Team. Our staff are also currently supporting one of the hotels housing the homeless community.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals to the service are made via Leeds City Council Housing Options.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: 3 meals a day 7 days a week are provided for those that stay.

support.supportInfo: Training and engagement is available and access to well being activities such as flu jabs physiotherapy etc.

name: Spenser Street – Supported Accommodation, Padiham
synopsis: Spenser Street is a generic service for young single people aged 16-25.
description: The project consists of 4 fully furnished, self-contained studio flats for 16–25 year old single people. Clients that stay in Spenser Street have a Floating Support Worker who works on a one-to-one basis, helping them to develop their independent living skills and address individual support needs

accommodation.referralNotes: For further information on this project or to make a referral please call or email us for a referral form.

support.supportInfo:
At the move-in stage, the allocated Floating Support Worker will complete an induction programme with each new client. Following this, they will arrange an appointment with the client to agree upon an initial support plan. The information from the initial support plan will form the basis for the development of a full support/action plan. The support/action plan will be devised and agreed with the client, Support Worker and any other agencies that the clients would like to be involved.

Support that can be offered, includes:

Help accessing and maintaining suitable long-term accommodation.
Advice on housing rights and responsibilities.
Help accessing specialist agencies around mental health issues.
Help accessing specialist services around substance/alcohol issues.
Help with applying for benefits, grants and loans.
Help with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts.
Help filling in forms (i.e. Welfare Benefits).
Support accessing specialist agencies and support services.
Support in accessing employment, voluntary work opportunities, training and education.
Help building self-confidence.
Support to develop shared living skills.

name: Spa Mill – Supported Accommodation, Burnley
synopsis: Approximately 1 mile from Burnley town centre, this project consists of 12 fully furnished self-contained flats for 16-25 year old single people who are homeless or in housing need.
description: At Spa Mill, each tenant has a Resettlement Worker who works with them on a one-to-one basis to develop both their independent living skills and address their individual support needs. On the premises there is also a training and events room used by residents and staff.

accommodation.referralNotes: For further information on this project or to make a referral please call or email us for a referral form.

support.supportInfo:
At the move-in stage, the allocated Resettlement Worker will complete an induction programme with each new client. Following this, they will arrange an appointment with the client to agree upon an initial support plan. The information from the initial support plan will form the basis for the development of a full support/action plan. The support/action plan will be devised and agreed with the client, Resettlement Worker and any other agencies that the clients would like to be involved.

Support that can be offered, includes:

Help accessing and maintaining suitable long term accommodation.
Advice on housing rights and responsibilities.
Help accessing specialist agencies around mental health issues.
Help accessing specialist services around substance/alcohol issues.
Help with applying for benefits, grants and loans.
Help with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts.
Help filling in forms (i.e. Welfare Benefits).
Support accessing specialist agencies and support services.
Support in accessing employment, voluntary work opportunities, training and education.
Help building self-confidence.
Support to develop shared living skills.

name: Southampton Alcohol Accommodation Service
synopsis: The Alcohol Accommodation-based Service provides supported housing to adults with histories of long-term and dependent alcohol misuse. The Service aims to support individuals to engage with appropriate treatment and reduce their alcohol intake through managed drinking and achieve improvement in their general health and wellbeing through better nutrition and access to other healthcare services.
description: The accommodation consists of three shared houses providing different levels of support depending on individual need. The service is staffed Monday – Friday from 9am-6pm and Saturday and Sunday for a few hours each day. Out of hours support is provided through the Society’s Operational Security Team which operates every night and at weekends. Each resident is encouraged to participate in the development of their own detailed support plan which highlights their medical needs, the aspects of their daily lives that they need the most support with, and their own aspirations for their future. Clients are given a named keyworker who supports them to stay on track with their goals in relation to their drinking and other aspects of their daily lives.  Access to the service is through referral from Social Services, the hospital discharge teams, alcohol services in the city, Social Services and the Street Homeless Prevention Team. All referrals that meet the Service criteria are followed up with an assessment to establish whether the service is appropriate for the individual. Informal visits are encouraged.  Priority will be given to individuals with a local connection to Southampton.   Individuals requiring 24 hour care will not be admitted.

name: Social Housing
synopsis: We advertise all our properties to rent along with some housing association properties through our Homechoice scheme. You can Register with Homechoice and place bids for properties that you would like to be considered for. &amp;#10;&amp;#10;https://www.stockporthomes.org/find-a-home/homes-to-rent/homechoice/
description:
Renting a home from Homechoice is a very popular option and we have more people applying for homes than properties becoming available. Therefore, it is important that you are flexible about the type and location of property you are willing to live in.

Stockport Homes has an Allocations Policy which details the awarding of points for your Homechoice application.

name: Smithfield Residential Detoxification Service
synopsis: Drug and alcohol detoxification.
description: Smithfield Detox is a 22 bed specialist inpatient treatment unit located in Manchester. The service provides drug and alcohol detoxifications in a clinically safe and supportive environment. All treatment programmes are flexible and tailored to individual needs and outcomes, to support a sustained recovery from addiction.

accommodation.referralNotes: Please call for further information in referrals.

name: Signposts One
synopsis: Stage One shelter in Luton
description: We have properties in Luton which provide short-term accommodation for single homeless people, of any gender, aged 16 - 64.

contact.name: Stage One
contact.additionalInfo:
> Telephone for SOS Emergency Accommodation: 01582722629, option 2;                                                                                      > Telephone for LUTON Stage 1: 01582 722629, option 3;
 > Telephone for DUNSTABLE Stage 1: 01582 722629, option 4.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you would like to refer someone or you would like to make a self-referral, please download and complete a referral form here - https://www.signpostsso.org/application-form.

name: Shaw Street Project
synopsis: The accommodation is for males and females age 16-21 who are ready for Tier 1 move on accommodation with low to medium support needs.
description:
The accommodation consists of 20 self-contained flats and we have availability for up to 2 couples.

We offer 2 disabled flats and have a lift available 24 hours a day. There are 2 sets of stairs for flats on the 1st and 2nd floors.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
Activities currently on offer at the Shaw Street include:
Library and DVD club,
Creative Arts Workshops provided by external agencies,
Cookery Classes,
Job club,
Therapeutic classes,
Gardening,
ESOL and external activities such as bowling trips, museum visits and access to outdoor activities.

We also offer resettlement and life skills sessions, I.T and digital support and help with CV’s and job applications etc.

support.supportInfo: On being accepted into the Support Service, you will be introduced to a member of our Support Team who will become your Support Worker, in effect your main point of support and contact within Shaw Street. You are required to engage with Support Services but the support offered to you will be tailored to your own needs. Your Support Worker will work with you to create a tailored support plan for you. &#10;&#10;The key areas are:&#10;Individual Support Planning,&#10;Achieving Economic Wellbeing through Education,&#10;Training and Employment,&#10;Welfare Advice and Debt Advice,&#10;Accessing primary and secondary health care,&#10;Housing Advice and support in accessing permanent accommodation,&#10;Accessing local support agencies.&#10;

name: Seaside CIC
synopsis: A social enterprise providing specialist housing and support for vulnerable people.
description:
We provide accommodation to socially vulnerable people (such as homeless people with mental health difficulties and/or substance/alcohol dependencies) with care, support or supervision according to their needs.

The Seaside team has over 30 years combined experience in working with vulnerable people. We have a proven track record of providing the highest quality of accommodation tailored for the needs and requirements of diverse client groups, and of providing a range of bespoke support services as required by local authorities and residents. 

We pride ourselves in delivering and maintaining the highest standards in our properties based on our vision of safe, clean, comfortable and supported housing for all our residents.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you'd like to apply to stay with us, please feel free to contact us.

support.supportInfo:
At Seaside CIC we pride ourselves on providing high quality standard accommodation. Our ethos is simple, we provide accommodation that we would be more than happy to stay in. Too often shared accommodation with intensive housing management is of a poor standard. 

Additionally we will work with tenants to maintain a high standard of cleanliness and hygiene, within rooms and communal areas. 

Currently we offer mostly single rooms for vulnerable homeless people, however we can accept applications from couples. Nearly all of our rooms are en suite, each room contains its own fridge, and comes with tea making facilities. Some rooms also have the additional benefit of a self-contained kitchenette, which are used for educational purposes only, as well as two communal kitchens and a communal lounge. Free WiFi is also available and accessible by residents.

name: Seacole Housing
synopsis: Mary Seacole Housing Association provides supported accommodation for single homeless people. A pathway to settled accommodation.
description:
Seacole House provides accommodation for single men who are more independent and aged 18 to 60 years.

We operate a range of accommodation services, from supported hostels, through to semi-independent housing, to help people at every stage of their journey into independence. We believe that a safe, stable and supported living environment is central to this.

We always take into consideration the needs of clients when allocating their accommodation and will support them with advice, guidance and encouragement. Their accommodation is a safe, warm, welcoming foundation from which they can start to rebuild their goals and aspirations for an independent, bright future.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you would like to refer someone or you would like to make a self-referral, please download and complete a referral form here - http://maryseacoleha.com/how-we-help/eligibility-and-referral/.

name: Saltbrook Place
synopsis: Temporary accommodation
description:
The building has 58 flats, 34 of which can house couples as well as single people. We have 7 flats with dog kennels that allow customers to have their dog on site. 

We complete a risk & needs assessment and affordability assessment before an offer of accommodation is made to ensure what we offer is appropriate for the individual. All our customers have a key worker who is their main point of contact for their support needs. However, we do have a team of staff who provide a 24 hour rota.  

The longest that someone can stay at the service is 2 years. However, we would aim to prepare someone for move on long before that. Our main focus is to work with our customers to enable them to gain the skills they need to move on to independent living. Providing a safe and secure environment is the first step in that journey.

accommodation.referralNotes: Access is via a referral from the Homeless Team at [Dudley MBC](https://www.dudley.gov.uk/residents/housing)

name: SPIN Hostel
synopsis: A 28-bed hostel for men, over 25 who are homeless.
description: The 28-bed hostel provides temporary accommodation and support for men over 25 who are homeless. We assist residents to find permanent accommodation, offer life skills and job advice and set up volunteering opportunities with FareShare, thereby establishing a work routine to get them ready for a working life.

accommodation.referralNotes: We accept self referrals as well as referrals via a professional body. Please call or email us to make a referral.

support.supportInfo: Fully staffed 24 hours a day

name: Ruth House
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide low support accommodation to 7 women aged 18 and upwards for 12 months.
* To support the mental health and or drug /alcohol misuse issues.
* To build and develop long term independent living skills for move on to independent accommodation or longer term supported accommodation.
* Each resident has individual 4 weekly support plans and key work sessions tailored to their needs to enable them to reach their goals and aspirations.
* Resident are supported to manage their own flat and help with budgeting skills.
* As part of their support, residents are offered weekly house meetings which enables them to be included in the day-to-day running and decisions in and around the project.
* Residents are encouraged to attend joint planning about the bigger picture of Petrus and the opportunity to meet other service users within Petrus projects.

The accommodation comprises self-contained flats.

accommodation.referralNotes: All referrals and queries should be made by way of the Mental Health Allocation Panel on 01706 654583.

name: Rough Sleepers Outreach Project (Wakefield) - Riverside
synopsis: Immediate safe place to sleep for rough sleepers
description:
Rough sleeprs are offered immediate safe place to sleep. This could in the Hub at Marsh Way House or in a hotel on a temporary basis whilst a longer term solution can be sought.

ROUGH SLEEPERS:
If you are rough sleeping in the district, please contact our Rough Sleeper Support Service who will be able to provide assistance that may not be available under duties assessed under the homeless legislation. You can contact Rough Sleepers Outreach Project (Wakefield) - Riverside on: 

* 01924 385722
* Email: RC&S.Wakefield@riverside.org.uk or
* Email: matthew.heald@riverside.org.uk

name: Regent Terrace
synopsis: Regent Terrace is located in a quiet residential area of Leeds and provides supported accommodation for 10 men who are dependent on alcohol.
description: The project provides outstanding care and assistance to the residents with the aim of encouraging them to gradually cut-down on their alcohol consumption as well as identifying and addressing their needs.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals are accepted via just about any source such as self, family, medical other agency. Staffed 24/7 with sleeping cover at night who are contactable in emergencies. The day staff work with the residents to be able to succeed their individual tailored support plans to help to achieve a better quality of health and well being.

features.additionalFeatures:
The house is a ‘wet’ project where residents are permitted to drink alcohol in the communal areas between 7.30am and 9.30pm. The house is staffed 24 hours a day with one team member staying overnight in case of any emergencies. 

Each resident has the privacy of their own bedroom as well as sharing the other facilities; the games room, dining area, bathrooms and TV lounge.  Regent Terrace also has its own private gardens for residents to enjoy during the nicer weather.  Breakfast, lunch and an evening meal are all available for residents each day.

support.supportInfo:
Residents who have reduced their alcohol levels to a level where they can healthily consider ending their drinking are fully supported by care staff and the Leeds Detoxification Unit.  Once a resident is no longer alcohol dependent we discuss with them their options for future accommodation.  For those residents who feel the need for extra support to remain abstinent we would recommend our sister project at Faith Lodge.

Residents are encouraged, where appropriate, to assist with daily tasks around the house.  Occasionally day trips are arranged by the support workers to local places of interest depending upon suitable funding.

name: Refuge Accommodation
synopsis: Our refuge base offers safe temporary accommodation, advice and support. Any Asian woman who is fleeing domestic abuse/forced marriages can refer herself to us directly or through an agency who is supporting her. We conduct pre-admission risk assessments to ensure our services are the right ones for the woman in question, this is imperative.

accommodation.referralNotes: Our refuge base offers safe temporary accommodation, advice and support. Any Asian woman who is fleeing domestic abuse/forced marriages can refer herself to us directly or through an agency who is supporting her. We conduct pre-admission risk assessments to ensure our services are the right ones for the woman in question, this is imperative.

name: Rapid Re-accommodation Welcome Centre
