synopsis: Emergency accommodation and wrap around support for anyone who would otherwise be rough sleeping.
description:
Emergency accommodation and wrap around support for anyone who would otherwise be rough sleeping.  Three meals a day are provided, along with support to access housing, medical services and other areas of support. 
- Open 24hours a day until 3rd May 2023
- Located at Haymarket Hub Hotel, 7 Clifton Terrace.

accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Three meals a day will be provided

name: Rankeillor Initiative
synopsis: Accommodation, advice and support for people moving towards more secure and settled housing. For those in the early stages of recovering from substance use, we can provide temporary accommodation in shared flats while you get back on your feet again.
description:
Applying for your own home can take between 9 to 14 months. During that time we can provide:

- information and support with housing and tenancies, including leases and deposits
- financial advice e.g. help with debt and budgeting, benefit and welfare rights
- employment support
- support to develop life skills  
- help with mental health issues and substance dependency
- support to access volunteering, training or education

### Your own Key Worker and Support Plan
You’ll have your own Key Worker who will give you plenty of support and encouragement to draw up your personal support plan. This will set out goals and define the outcomes you want to achieve.

### Who can use this service?
You can use this service if you are:

- Male
- Over 18 years of age
- Homeless and with a local connection to Edinburgh
- living in recovery from substance use

### Want to know more?
Call us on 0131 225 4901

name: Prospective Pathway Futures
synopsis: Supported Accommodation for the vulnerable adult, male or female, aged 18 and over who must be on benefits and have a support need.
description: Our service is a residential service for vulnerable single men and women aged 18 and over who are rough sleeping, vulnerably housed, homeless or at risk of becoming homeless who may have a mental health issue, addiction or offending history. The accommodation is provided for individuals with support needs who are willing to engage with us or other providers and appropriate agencies in order to address their support needs as part of the support planning process. We accept referrals from voluntary organisations, statutory organisations and self-referrals.

name: Prospect Lodge
synopsis: Prospect Lodge is a 15 bed single homeless hostel for individuals aged 18+.
description:
The hostel consists of 15 generic en-suite bedrooms of which includes 3 complex care beds. 

The project has one fully accessible disabled assess room, ground floor including wet room. All rooms are fully furnished, including flat screen TV, Fridge, Kettle, Toasters and are newly refurbished to a high standard. 

There are shared kitchens on each floor of the building; and a large communal kitchen with 4 cookers on the ground floor. Laundry facilities are provided with washer, dryer, iron and vacuum cleaners.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

support.supportInfo:
Residents will be allocated a keyworker, and also a secondary keyworker (who will support the case if the main keyworker is unavailable). Individual support packages will be put in place with full risk assessment to create a safe environment for all the residences and staff team. 

Support sessions will take place on a weekly basis. All tenants are required to engage with their Keyworkers as part of the Licence Agreement. 

A clear and realistic support plan will be put in place with achievable goals in various areas to worked towards, potential move-on options available and progressing forwards with the Tenancy Ready Resettlement Programme. 

*Length of stay is anticipated to be up to 6 months.*

name: Portsmouth Foyer
synopsis: 48 bed hostel for people aged 16-25
description: Young single homeless or inappropriately housed people aged 16-25, with low to medium support needs. All referrals are made through the young persons' housing panel managed by Portsmouth Housing Options.

name: People First Social Housing
synopsis: Housing Association offering accommodation services to people experiencing homelessness
description: We own and manage high quality housing in Hulme, Manchester and provide community support services across North-West England. We provide support in helping people move from temporary accommodation.

accommodation.referralNotes: Please contact us on admin@peoplefirsthousing.co.uk or 0161 235 6900

name: Pendlebury House
synopsis: Rehabilitation and recovery service for people who have psychosis.
description: Pendlebury House provides a rehabilitation and recovery service for people who have psychosis. We specialise in supporting people with active schizophrenia to be able to comfortably use facilities within the community, leading to a more independent lifestyle. We support men between the ages of 18 and 65 who have an initial medical diagnosis of psychosis.

accommodation.referralNotes: For more information or to make a referral or self referral, please contact us.

name: Patrick House
description: Patrick House is a 56 room assessment centre, with shared facilities and full-board catered service.  There is 24 hour support on site and all clients are allocated a support worker for the duration of any stay.  For referral information please contact Patrick House directly

contact.name: TwoSaints
contact.additionalInfo:
Who do we help?
Single homeless people. Priority given to people with a Southampton connection. Can accept couples and applicants with dogs.
Who we cannot help
Those who are heavily under the influence of alcohol or drugs at time of referral. May not accept people with a history of repeated serious violence or arson, but will assess each applicant individually.
Minimum age accepted: 18
Maximum age accepted: 60

name: Pathway Project
synopsis: Homeless shelter.
description: Hostel providing temporary accommodation for single homeless people who need housing urgently and who can't get help from the council.

accommodation.referralNotes: Call us on 01582 451315.

name: P3 Sandwell Women's Service
synopsis: Supported housing project for women with mental health issues.
description:
We provide a 10 bed, 24 hour staffed supported housing project for women with mental health issues.

This is an age 18-65 women only service for those with mental health issues.

We will accept women through: Self referral, Crisis Home Treatment Team, G.P., Support Services, Community Mental Health Trust, PCLT

7 rooms are designated for the accommodation of clients with Mental Health difficulties who require tenancy related support. Women accessing this service have a comprehensive assessment of need and are then involved in the formulation of a support plan designed to address these needs. This plan is then followed and regularly reviewed with the aim of promoting independence in the future.

name: Orrell Lane
synopsis: The project at Orrell Lane provides a service to single males and females, aged 16+.&#10;It also offers a high risk high needs service to single males and females, aged 18+.
description:
The project has 8 bedrooms including 4 High Risk High Needs beds. Each bedroom is fully furnished and includes; flat screen TV, fridge, worktop and kettle.

There are no ground floor rooms at this project and each floor is accessible by stairs only.

contact.name: Unavailable at present
contact.additionalInfo:
The contact number for the High Risk High Needs service at Orrell Lane is: 0151 329 2772 extension 500

[Excel Housing Solutions' Website](https://www.excelhousingsolutions.com/accommodation/)

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
We offer the following activities: gardening projects, football/fitness, ICT workshops, cookery classes, fishing trips, health groups and numeracy and literacy Workshops. 

We have a full time qualified trainer who is actively engaged in the delivery of in-house training events such as the Trusted Tenants award.

In addition we also work with other professional training organisations such as; CRISIS, Alder Training and Cisco training.

Residents will also have access to other opportunities at Liverpool YMCA, Leeds Street.

support.supportInfo: Residents will be allocated a Support Worker who will facilitate formal weekly key working sessions with the resident. We will also allocate a Secondary Support Worker who will provide support for them if their Support Worker is unavailable. All residents are required to engage with the Support Services as part of their license agreement.

name: Olivia Lodge
synopsis: Olivia Lodge is a supported housing project for young women aged between 16 and 25 years old who are either pregnant or have children up to the age of 5.
description:
Olivia Lodge is purpose built accommodation, consisting of twelve self-contained flats. We provide a home in the heart of Manchester, close to local shops and with excellent transport links to the city centre.

All accommodation is furnished to a high standard, including a fridge, cooking utensils, soft furnishings, bed, bedroom furniture and a baby cot in the studios, while the flats and bungalow also have white goods provided. Other facilities include: intercom to office, garden and outdoor play area and residents’ pay phone. There are ground floor flats and studios available and disabled toilet facilities and a lift to the upper floor.

We may not be able to accept applicants who: have been convicted of hurting or neglecting a child, have a history of arson, use class A drugs and don’t want help to stop, have a history of violence or threatening behaviour, are not willing to work with others in order to get on in life.

accommodation.referralNotes:
If you wish to refer to the service or you would like to
come and have a look around Olivia Lodge please
call: 0161 230 3730 or email: olivialodge@greatplaces.org.uk

support.supportInfo: We offer 24 hour support and advice from staff who care - with managing money, your health, independent living, getting welfare and housing benefits, education, training and employment and helping you find a long term home in the future.

name: Oldham Young People Pathway (OYPP)
synopsis: Oldham Young People Pathway provides accommodation for young people aged 16 - 23 in Oldham.
description:
Commissioned by Oldham Metropolitan Borough Council we work with young people aged 16-25 who are homeless or at risk of homelessness in the Oldham area. We offer different types of accommodation for young people, from high support 24-hour staffed projects to flats in the community to supported lodgings with a host family. Our work is about breaking the cycles of homelessness and helping young people work through the behaviours that prevent them moving on and finding stable accommodation. 
We do not label our young people as "homeless" - they are individual, charismatic and full of potential. Their situation is not what defines them. 
Our team encourages engagement through enjoyable activities; we run cooking groups, art sessions, drop- ins and work shops. We also offer support sessions which allow young people to set realistic goals. We support young people to attend appointments, help them to enrol at college, or support them with a food shop.
We have an employment, education training and volunteer coordinator, to support the young people we work with. Young people have started plastering, playing football and online IT courses & many other exciting opportunities.

name: Oak House
synopsis: A safe, secure and stable living environment. (20 Beds)
description:
Only accessible via referral: https://theashleyfoundation.org.uk/services/how-to-access-us/

Our staff and volunteers help clients work through their issues and support them in gaining the confidence and stability needed to be able to manage and sustain themselves.

We provide four meals a day with a varied, healthy, and seasonally adjusted menu. Plus we provide options for people who may have any allergies or specific dietary requirements, such as being vegetarian.

Our team of chefs and housekeepers also provide residents with domestic skills training to help prepare them for semi or fully independent living.

More information can be found here: https://theashleyfoundation.org.uk/services/accommodation/

name: Nottingham Arimathea Trust
synopsis: Supported accommodation for refugees and asylum seekers
description: Supported accommodation for refugees and asylum seekers

accommodation.referralNotes: Referals from partner agencies, for example Nottingham and Notts Refugee Forum

features.additionalFeatures: Due to COVID restrictions no visitors are currently allowed.

support.supportInfo: where support is..

name: No Longer Available
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* This project provides housing with support for four single female residents who have low-level housing support needs. 
* The service has been designed for individuals who may be socially isolated but do not have high support needs. Prospective residents may struggle to maintain their own tenancies without some general housing management support.
* The support we will provide can include help with budgeting, advocacy, support with managing income/benefits and debt issues.
* Staff will also support residents with obtaining move on accommodation through our links with R.M.B.C. and the Bond Board when appropriate. 
* Residents will be expected to attend key work sessions with staff and complete a needs assessment/support plan.

The accommodation comprises of four large bedrooms with a shared kitchen, living room and two shared bathrooms. The bedrooms are fully furnished and the kitchen has been stocked with cooking utensils.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Nightstop Service
synopsis: Emergency short-term accommodation to homeless young people 16-21 years old.
description:
The Nightstop Service in Leeds offers short-term accommodation to homeless young people 16-21 years in Leeds. 

This service is provided by volunteers providing accommodation for 1-3 nights within their own homes. Barnardo's future's recruits, trains and carry's out safety checks on the volunteers and their homes. We continue to supervise and train our volunteers.

contact.telephone: Office number 0113 2395560/ Nightstop referral number is 0113 2307888

accommodation.referralNotes: The young person in question would need to be referred by a partner agency such as housing, police, education. These agencies can then hopefully work with the young people to ensure longer term accommodation. The Nightstop referral number is 0113 2307888.

name: Nightstop Greater Manchester
synopsis: Nightstop is a youth homeless prevention service. We place young people at risk of homelessness with a volunteer host on a night-by-night basis.
description:
Nightstop is a unique community based solution to youth homelessness, which places young homeless people in the homes of trained volunteers, ordinary people in the community who have a spare room and want to help young people in need.

Nightstop hosts provide a private room, a warm meal and somewhere safe to stay for the night, whilst Nightstop helps to find a permanent solution to their homelessness.

name: Nightstop Greater Manchester
synopsis: Nightstop Greater Manchester provides emergency accommodation for young people aged 16 to 25 who are at risk of homelessness in volunteers homes with hosts who have been trained and vetted.
description: If you live in Oldham, have a suitable spare room and want to help young people, please call us on 0161 624 9155 from Monday to Friday, 9am-5pm, or email: porter.street@depaulcharity.org.uk

name: New Beginnings Dispersed Housing
synopsis: The service provides 26 self-contained units which are fully furnished accommodation with a bathroom and fully equipped kitchen. Each building has a private garden.
description:
New Beginnings Dispersed Housing Scheme works in partnership with Liverpool Mutual Homes (LMH) to offer support to 26 individuals who are homeless/ at risk of homelessness and have support needs. 

We provide good quality temporary accommodation and create an environment that enables individuals to develop skills to manage their own future independent tenancies. 

Each Client is allocated a worker to formulate and implement an individual support package which can include external agency input if appropriate. A risk management approach is undertaken to assist with move on plans.

accommodation.referralNotes:
Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk/

Homeless clients should contact the Housing Options service of the Liverpool City Council for assessment to be matched to the appropriate service. This can be done by contacting **0151 233 3044**. More information can also be found [here](https://liverpool.gov.uk/housing/homeless-or-at-risk/housing-options-referral/).
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Individuals are responsible for their own meals.

support.supportInfo:
The support plan is client led and based on clearly defined outcomes. Both the support plan and risk plan are reviewed on a regular basis, with the timing of the reviews also responsive to the individual client needs.

Typical support areas include issues associated with any of the following:

Welfare and benefits advice,
Putting in place safeguards to stabilise and manage crisis situations,
Move on Plans,
Tackle any barriers to re-housing, such as payment plans for rent arrears,
Debt issues,
Correspondence/ form filling,
Rent/council tax arrears,
Payment of rent / bills,
CCG and social fund applications,
Money management/budgeting,
Managing tenancy,
Social isolation,
Education/employment/training,
Learning difficulties,
Offending.

The Client and project worker will agree the overall support objectives and the actions required to achieve successful move-on and will use this to predict a date of move-on. The service works in partnership with LMH and other providers to empower clients to move on to mainstream housing.


Staff

The service is staffed by two Project Workers and a Team Manager. Staff work Monday to Friday 9-5 and are based at Edge Lane during this time, staff are flexible and offer regular contact to each client to meet their support needs.

name: Morning Star Hostel
synopsis: Supported accommodation for single homeless men aged 30+ with an emphasis on rough sleepers and and/or those with alcohol issues and a Manchester connection.
description:
Family visitors are allowed with staff permission, no overnight guests allowed.

Due to limited resources we cannot accommodate anyone with confirmed mental health conditions requiring specialist support or ex violent/sexual offenders.

address.publicTransportInfo: Buses 85, 101, 104, 109. Oxford Road train station is a 20 minute walk away.

accommodation.referralNotes: The Morning Star Hostel accepts both self and agency referrals. We may accept applications from offenders with background information and references. To refer, please call in Mon - Fri, 9am - 5pm. Alternatively, please call in at the Cornerstone Day Centre next door, Mon - Fri, 10:30am - 4pm.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Weekly charge required from residents in receipt of benefits.

name: Milner Court
synopsis: Emergency accommodation for 16 - 25 year olds
description:
Milner Court (Bordesley) provides emergency accommodation for single men and women age 16 to 25, for up to three months while a full assessment of their support needs is carried out and appropriate longer-term accommodation is found for them in fully supportive or semi-independent accommodation. Milner Court is staffed 24 hours a day so there is always someone on hand to help with advice.

Accommodation comprises of 25 single rooms, each with an en-suite shower. The shared communal facility consists of a Training Kitchen, Dining Area, Laundry, IT Suite and a small Gym.

There is disabled access to the ground floor areas

name: Mildmay House
synopsis: Mildmay House is a 48 bed supported accommodation project for men and women aged 16+.
description:
The accommodation comprises of 37 en-suite bedrooms with shared kitchens and lounges and 11 fully self-contained flats used in preparation for move on.

Mildmay House is fully furnished and all new clients are provided with essential move in items such as bedding and toiletries.

Mildmay House has a lift and stair lift providing an environment that is accessible and inclusive.

Mildmay House is self-catering with exception to our breakfast club and weekly Sunday Dinner. 

Dogs will be considered at point of offer of accommodation, subject to information recorded on Mainstay, completion of a risk assessment and a commitment to working with the PDSA.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
Mildmay House has a large internet style cafe area in the centre of the building on the ground floor providing a relaxed space for clients and 24 hour internet accessible computers, additionally there is a training kitchen, pool table and television.

Mildmay House also has a small gym located on the lower ground floor accessible following an induction, music studio and our treatment room is utilised by outside agencies to deliver in- house essential healthcare.

support.supportInfo:
Once you have been accepted into Mildmay House you will be supported by an Allocation Worker whose main role is to help you settle into Mildmay and start working with you to explore areas of support you require. 

They will work with you for the first two weeks and support you with prioritising essential things such as setting up benefits and getting you registered with a GP. 

After the first two weeks you will be passed over to your support worker after successful completion of a needs assessment, your allocated worker will support you to achieve all the goals that have been identified. Your support package will be personally tailored for you and is reviewed on a quarterly basis. 

Engagement with your allocated worker is a condition of your Licence Agreement and the expectation is you will meet with your support worker on a regular basis. 

Once it is agreed you are ready to move on and you have completed our in-house six week tenancy training sessions you will be eligible to move to one of our self- contained flats whilst waiting for a successful offer of permanent accommodation through agreed housing routes such as PropertyPool. 

Support is also available through our own resettlement worker to ensure a successful transition to independent living. 

All clients leaving Mildmay House in a planned way are eligible to continue accessing the facilities as part of our commitment to ensuring successful move on.

name: Mildenhall House
synopsis: Semi-Supported scheme
description:
Mildenhall House, a Semi-Supported scheme five minutes walk from the centre of Solihull, provides accommodation and support services for 12 young men and women who must have been living in Solihull prior to becoming homeless for at least 5 years. All the young people accommodated have their own self-contained bedsits only the laundry and training room facilities are shared. The aim of the service is to support the young people within the project to gain opportunities, experience and skills to enable young people to prepare for independent living.

Young people can stay for up to a maximum of two years. In that time staff will work closely with young people to help them access opportunities which will build their skills and confidence and support them to access education, training and employment opportunities so that young people can move on and be truly independent.

Staff work with those leaving the service to ensure they move on in a planned fashion.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals are taken through Solihull Community Housing. Tel: 0121 717 1515.

name: Midland House
synopsis: Supported accommodation.
description: Midland House provides up to 78 residents with a stable place to live and continue their journeys towards independence.

accommodation.referralNotes: Please call us to make a referral and we will send you a referral form.

name: Michael House
synopsis: Based in the heart of Boscombe, Michael House offers a safe, supported, drug and alcohol-free environment for people rebuilding their lives. The main house has eighteen spaces for men and women with another eight next door in our neighbouring move-on accommodation. We are one of the few dog-friendly hostels in the UK and are able to accept rough sleepers with pets where appropriate.
description:
We offer a shared community environment, where each resident is assigned a Support Worker and encouraged to overcome potential barriers to independent living.

Our staff team have a vast amount of practical experience within various homelessness settings and are used to working with vulnerable adults including those with learning difficulties, offender rehabilitation, addiction support, surviving domestic abuse, and mental health first aid. 

We take a strength-based approach to encourage our residents to engage with the life of the house, try new things, and build their self-esteem.

Our ever-changing programme of in-house activities has included baking, creative writing, sewing, arts, crafts, conservation projects and minibus outings. Most of these are led by staff or volunteers, but sometimes current and former residents share their talents with others. Many of these activities have been adapted to be Covid Safe and in line with current Government guidance.

We are currently running 2-2-1 workshops to increase peer mentoring and where possible we are utilising our award-winning wildlife garden (created soley by residents) for smaller group activities.

In addition to our support planning, residents are also offered the opportunity to have their achievements formally recognised through an accreditation scheme to support their personal and/or career development.

name: Mary Seacole House
synopsis: Mary Seacole Housing Association provides supported accommodation for single homeless people. A pathway to settled accommodation.
description:
Mary Seacole House provides accommodation for clients between 16 and 25 years. Residents are supported 24 hours a day with a full range of activities along with training sessions in our dedicated Training Unit.

We operate a range of accommodation services, from supported hostels, through to semi-independent housing, to help people at every stage of their journey into independence. We believe that a safe, stable and supported living environment is central to this.

We always take into consideration the needs of clients when allocating their accommodation and will support them with advice, guidance and encouragement. Their accommodation is a safe, warm, welcoming foundation from which they can start to rebuild their goals and aspirations for an independent, bright future.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you would like to refer someone or you would like to make a self-referral, please download and complete a referral form here - http://maryseacoleha.com/how-we-help/eligibility-and-referral/.

name: Male Only Service, Heywood (Ashburn House)
synopsis: Ashburn House offers supported accommodation for single men aged 18 and over who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.
description:
The service consists of 13 self-contained fully furnished flats in a grouped accommodation setting at Ashburn House with communal facilities including garden, meeting room, and access to IT. We also offer another 15 independent properties dispersed within the community.

Our staff based at Ashburn House in Heywood are available 24/7, working with clients on a one-to-one basis to deliver a package of support that is specific to individual needs. Staff specialise in delivering housing-related support but will work with a variety of specialist service providers in order to deliver a coordinated approach for people who have additional support needs.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals to the service can be made by requesting a referral form from our Central Referral Team via email. Once a referral form is received, we will arrange a Needs Assessment interview with the applicant; if they meet the criteria they will be placed on the waiting list for service.

support.supportInfo:
At the move-in stage, the allocated Resettlement Worker will complete an induction programme with each new client. Following this, they will arrange an appointment with the client to agree upon a support plan, which is devised and agreed with the client, Resettlement Worker and any other agencies that the clients would like to be involved.

Support that can be offered, include:

Advice on housing rights and responsibilities.
Support to develop the skills and capacity needed to meet their obligations as a tenant.
Support accessing specialist agencies e.g. mental health and substance misuse issues.
Support in applying for benefits, grants and loans (including help with forms).
Support to assist individuals with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts etc.
Joint Working with specialist support services/agencies.
Support in accessing employment, voluntary work opportunities, training and education.
Help building self-confidence.
Support to develop independent living skills, including in a shared environment.
Help to access and maintain suitable long-term accommodation when the client is ready to move on.

name: Lorna Lodge
synopsis: Lorna Lodge is a purpose built supported housing scheme for young female parents aged 16-25, who have children less than 5yrs old or who are expecting.
description:
We aim to enable single young parents and their children to access the support that they need in-order to gain the skills and foundations for independent living and encourage future long term tenancy sustainment.

We provide one and two bedroomed, self contained units with onsite support staff, in the heart of Wythenshawe, close to local shops with excellent transport links.

We may not be able to accept applicants who: have been convicted of hurting or neglecting a child, have a history of arson, use class A drugs and don’t want help to stop, have a history of violence or threatening behaviour, are not willing to work with others in order to get on
in life.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you wish to refer to the service or you would like to come and have a look around Lorna Lodge please call: 0161 437 3102 or email: lornalodge@greatplaces.org.uk&#10;&#10;&#10;

support.supportInfo: We offer 24 hour support and advice from staff who care - with managing money, your health, independent living, getting welfare and housing benefits, education, training and employment and helping you find a long term home in the future.

name: Long-term Low-Level General Needs, Middleton (Parkside)
synopsis: Parkside offers accommodation with enhanced housing management to people aged 18 and over who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.
description:
The service consists of 14 self-contained fully furnished flats in a grouped accommodation setting at Parkside with communal facilities, including gardens, laundry and access to IT. The project is staffed by a part-time Housing Officer who supports clients with long-term, low-level support needs in managing and sustaining their accommodation and independence. We also offer other properties dispersed in the community.

The on-site Housing Officer provides an enhanced housing management service including repairs reporting and general housing-related advice to tenants.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals to the scheme can be made by requesting a referral form from our Central Referral Team via email. Once a completed referral form is received, we will arrange a Needs Assessment interview with the applicant; if they meet the criteria they will be placed on the waiting list for the project.

support.supportInfo:
At the move-in stage the Housing Officer will complete an induction programme with each new tenant. The Housing Officer will offer housing related advice and guidance to assist the tenant in managing their tenancy.

Assistance that can be offered, include:

Help complying with the terms of the tenancy.
Advice on housing rights and responsibilities.
Help with applying for benefits, grants and loans.
Help with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts.
Help filling in forms. (i.e. Welfare Benefits).
Advice and assistance with security regarding the tenant’s home.
Managing breaches of tenancy conditions including anti-social behaviour, noise nuisance.

name: Long Street
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide accommodation for 10 single men and women with support needs.
* To operate a high quality supported accommodation project that meets the basic needs of our residents.
* To provide health and wellbeing services.
* To identify move on opportunities for residents using key working and case management.
* To assist residents and the wider community to take part in group activities and advice sessions which promote personal well-being and independent living skills.
* Each resident is assessed individually to determine their support needs. They are allocated a key worker who works with them to put together a support plan that aims to help develop skills and will enable the service user to live more independently.
* Long Street works closely with a wide range of other agencies to help provide a comprehensive package of help, tailored to each individual's needs. 
* Support can include help with budgeting, literacy, advice, advocacy, social skills, and referrals to specialist agencies, educational & training opportunities, volunteering & employment. 
* Residents are provided with move-on support to access independent accommodation and training/education opportunities. 
* Group work and activity sessions are provided to help residents to improve their personal wellbeing, self-confidence and independent living skills.

The accommodation comprises six en-suite bedrooms, four self-contained flats and shared lounge, kitchen, laundry and washing facilities. There is one ground-floor en-suite bedroom, which can provide accommodation for men or women with limited mobility.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Lister Road
synopsis: 16 beds of supported accommodation for males and females over 16 who have no access to settled accommodation.
description:
Facilities include single bedrooms and some shared amenities. The accommodation is also shared across Lister and Ullet Road, which creates 28 units in total and a comfortable secure environment.

Residents are allocated a support worker who will work with the residents to achieve support goals and work to resettlement into more long term accommodation options.

All residents can also access all the involvement opportunities at Liverpool YMCA, Leeds Street and vice versa.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via https://liverpool.gov.uk/housing/homeless-or-at-risk/

features.additionalFeatures:
ACTIVITIES ON OFFER -
 
Activities currently on offer at Ullet Road & Lister Road include:
  Cooking on a Budget Classes
  Drama Group
  Men’s Health & Wellbeing Groups
  ICT Workshops
  Art Group
  Cinema/Movie Nights
  Breakfast Clubs
  Sunday Dinner Clubs
  Bicycle Maintenance Workshops
Football
  Gardening Projects
  Pool Table

support.supportInfo:
On being accepted into the Support Service residents will be introduced and allocated to a member of our Support Team who will become their Key Worker. All residents will also be allocated a Secondary Key Worker who will provide support for them if their initial allocated Key Worker is unavailable. All residents are required to engage with Support Services as part of their license agreement and the support offered to them will be tailored to meet and address their own individual support needs.

We have a full time Resettlement Worker who will work alongside the support team and is also actively involved in all forms of resettlement for each individual. We currently have several professional training providers running educational programmes through external providers.

name: Lighthouse Shirebrook
synopsis: Lighthouse Shirebrook
description:
We accept self-referrals and professional referrals and engage in a careful process of assessment on both sides, prior to admission.Involvement in any faith-based activity is entirely optional and without any pressure or requirement.  

Our projects have weekly services and daily devotions and a number of residents choose to be engaged in these activities.

We run four facilities which are drug and alcohol free and an understanding of this requirement is a key factor in admission assessments. Coming to live at Lighthouse sets the bar high for some of our residents and requires high levels of motivation to change long established patterns of drug and alcohol use.

We do not accommodate those with a history of, or current charges relating to, sexual offending or arson with intent to endanger life.

For a small number of residents, we will consider long term residence, as a place of safety and protection.

name: Lighthouse Rotherham
synopsis: Lighthouse Rotherham
description:
We accept self-referrals and professional referrals and engage in a careful process of assessment on both sides, prior to admission.

Involvement in any faith-based activity is entirely optional and without any pressure or requirement.  Our projects have weekly services and daily devotions and a number of residents choose to be engaged in these activities.

We run four facilities which are drug and alcohol free and an understanding of this requirement is a key factor in admission assessments. Coming to live at Lighthouse sets the bar high for some of our residents and requires high levels of motivation to change long established patterns of drug and alcohol use. 

We do not accommodate those with a history of, or current charges relating to, sexual offending or arson with intent to endanger life.   

For a small number of residents, we will consider long term residence, as a place of safety and protection.

name: Leigh Bank Residential Rehabilitation
synopsis: Addiction recovery rehabilitation.
description: Leigh Bank is a 16 bed recovery project in Oldham, providing effective person-centred treatment to individuals with addiction. It offers a safe environment where individuals can embrace support from the peer group, participate in structured daily activities, become independent, and engage with the community around them free of substances.

accommodation.referralNotes: For more information or to make a referral or self referral, please contact us.

name: Leeds Street
synopsis: The primary aim of Liverpool YMCA is for people to move towards independent living. Our focus remains on recovery and enabling people to achieve their individual potential.&#10;&#10;The accommodation provided at Liverpool YMCA - Complex Needs Leeds Street, consists of 10 rooms.
description: Liverpool YMCA provides psychologically informed support and accommodation for people with complex needs. We provide intensive support rooted in the principles of Trauma Informed Care and Cognitive Analytic Therapy and work closely with external partners to ensure that additional support is accessed in a flexible, meaningful and person centred way.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via https://liverpool.gov.uk/housing/homeless-or-at-risk/

features.additionalFeatures:
Activities currently on offer at the YMCA include:
It’s Your Move (Resettlement and Life Skills sessions),
Women’s Group,
Chaplain’s Drop In,
Art Therapy,
Lakeside Residential Week, 
Cultures for Life,
Social Activities,
Resident’s Meetings,
Resident’s Panel Meetings,
Resident Consultations,
Dutch Farm (Gardening Project)

Learning, Development & Employment Drop In

support.supportInfo:
Support

On acceptance into the Support and Accommodation Service you will receive a full induction and will be introduced to your key worker and other members of the support team. We will work with you to understand your situation and the things you would like to work towards. We will work with you to plan your support and use Outcome Star or other mapping exercises to create a support plan that works for you.

We have a highly skilled team of support staff who are all here to assist you and two full time dedicated Learning and Development Officers who work alongside the support team and are also actively involved in facilitating group work and activities. They provide further support surrounding training and educational development to those residents who require it. All new residents will also be required to attend a Health & Safety and policy induction which is facilitated by staff & resident mentors.

Staff

This service will be staffed by 3 Intensive Support Practitioners and will be supported by 2 Domiciliary workers alongside the Support Manager and Housing Services Manager.

name: Knowsley Supported Housing - Blackpool
synopsis: There&rsquo;s nothing quite like a place of your own to give you a real sense of independence, especially when there is a qualified team of professionals around to provide you with the care and support you need.
description:
Our Knowsley supported housing services combine accommodation with varying levels of care and support. Depending on your individual requirements, we have different types of supported housing and supported living services available to you, including short-term, long-term, and temporary accommodation in case of an emergency.

This combination of housing and personalised support is ideal for people with mental health conditions and learning disabilities, for older people and for those living with dementia, who want to have their own independence but the assurance of a care package suited to their requirements

-IMPORTANT NOTE-
The location listed here is simply for the offices where you must go to arrange the accommodation, not the location of the accommodation itself.

name: Karibu
synopsis: Temporary accommodation for single men and women aged 18+
description: Karibu House offers temporary accommodation for single men and women aged 18+ who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, including refugees.

features.additionalFeatures: There are 16 furnished rooms with en-suite shower room and toilet, spacious communal TV lounge, laundry room and communal kitchens. The building is secured and offers free WiFi.

support.supportInfo:
Staff are on-site as follows:

    9am – 6pm Monday to Friday
    12noon – 4pm Saturday and Sunday

There is a night service from 10pm to 6am Monday to Sunday, and an out of hours emergency service.

name: Julian House Women Only House
synopsis: Julian House manage a small, 2 bed house for women only in Exeter providing short term accommodation and support.  We take a Trauma informed approach to supporting women who are recovering from homelessness.
description: Women are encouraged to devise their own support plan which will ensure any issues such as debt, mental and physical health, relationships, loneliness and boredom are addressed prior to a move into a long term tenancy.

name: Jimmy's Assessment Centre and emergency accommodation
synopsis: 20 emergency en-suite beds
description:
Providing short-term, emergency accommodation for adult men and women who might otherwise find themselves sleeping rough on the streets of Cambridge or vulnerably housed. Jimmy’s Assessment Centre offers far more than a bed for the night.

Here you’ll have access to:
* A resettlement and re-connection service to work with you to find a more suitable place to live long-term.
* En-suite rooms, laundry facilities and freshly prepared daily meals.

accommodation.referralNotes: Jimmys takes referrals from organisations such as the Street Outreach Team, Wintercomfort and Cambridge City Council.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Residents are provided with breakfast, lunch and cooked dinner.

support.supportInfo: Full time, 24 hour support, keyworker based.

name: Intact Projects Ltd - Trafford
synopsis: Intact Projects Ltd ethos is that young people who come into our care need the SUPPORT &ndash; GUIDANCE &ndash; ASSURANCE good quality CARE and age &ndash; appropriate accommodation everything Intact offers. We offer placements to the young person&rsquo;s we feel will be committed to engage with the support provided.&#10;&#10;We would hope the young person stays with us at least five nights per week, undertakes to participate in developing their life skills and make a commitment to finding positive ways to manage their time.

accommodation.referralNotes: Please complete an online referral form by visitig https://intactprojects.co.uk/referrals/.

support.supportInfo:
**ACCOMODATION AND MANAGEMENT SERVICES**
* Placement cost includes all management and service delivery plus breakfast seven mornings per week.
* Placement pricing is determined by the individual support needs of the young person, this should be discussed and confirmed at referral stage.
* There is a separate service charge which covers all utilities, washing/ ironing facilities and wi-fi, payment for SC to be confirmed at start of placement, if this is to be paid by the local authority or the individual young person from their allowance.
* A breakfast of cereal, egg and toast is available weekday mornings and a cooked breakfast is available Saturday and Sunday.
* Intact also provide a cooked evening meal Monday to Friday.

**INDIVIDUAL SUPPORT SERVICES**
* Provide an Independence Programme and key worker to support for each young person to develop their social skills and access appropriate employment and educational opportunities by, for example, working closely with local training providers
* Advocate for the young person in their formal representation either by telephone or in person, for example, accompanying them/preparing them for interviews
* Encourage the young person to establish their own links with external agencies and local organisations, community resources and leisure outlets
* Provide advice and signposting regarding alcohol, drugs, sexual health, healthy living, safety on a formal and informal level
* Assist the young person with their personal finances, for example, opening a bank account, accessing benefits and managing their money
 * A Weekly Planner and monthly progress reports covering all aspects of their lives where signposting is provided and positive action plans are produced
 * Attending and hosting LAC and other reviews with external professionals to ensure that each young person is working towards their goals

name: Intact Projects Ltd - Stockport
synopsis: Intact Projects Ltd ethos is that young people who come into our care need the SUPPORT &ndash; GUIDANCE &ndash; ASSURANCE good quality CARE and age &ndash; appropriate accommodation everything Intact offers. We offer placements to the young person&rsquo;s we feel will be committed to engage with the support provided.&#10;&#10;We would hope the young person stays with us at least five nights per week, undertakes to participate in developing their life skills and make a commitment to finding positive ways to manage their time.

name: Independence House
synopsis: Accommodation for homeless people.
description: A modern lifehouse containing single rooms for individuals experiencing homelessness with support services delivered by a partner managing agent in a residential location.

contact.name: Manchester City Council
contact.additionalInfo: This property is allocated through Manchester City Council's housing register - Manchester Move. To register your interest, please make contact with Manchester City Council.

accommodation.referralNotes: To register your interest in this property, please make contact with Manchester City Council.

name: Imaani House
synopsis: Temporary accommodation for single women
description: Temporary accommodation for single women aged 16-34 who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.

contact.name: Imaani House
contact.additionalInfo: Staff are on-site as follows:&#10;&#10;    9am &ndash; 8pm Monday to Thursday&#10;    9am &ndash; 6pm Friday&#10;    10am &ndash; 2pm Saturday and Sunday&#10;&#10;There is an out of hours emergency service.

features.additionalFeatures: There are 10 furnished rooms with en-suite shower rooms, spacious communal TV lounge and communal kitchen. All rooms are fully furnished to a high standard, including the provision of bed linen. The building is secured and offers free WiFi. There are also 4 self-contained ‘move-on’ flats, and 4 rooms in 2 shared houses.

support.supportInfo:
Support is offered based on individually-assessed needs. Residents are encouraged to take control of their lives, increase their confidence and self-esteem, and make informed choices about their future.

All residents who are not already engaged in some form of training, education or employment are actively encouraged to do so. Staff provide information and advice, and work in partnership with local colleges and training agencies to assist residents in making choices about their education. 

Residents usually stay for up to 3 months; this can be extended in exceptional circumstances.

name: Howcroft
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide low level support accommodation to 6 single women and men aged 18 and upwards. The length of stay is determined by Petrus.
* To support the mental health and or drug/alcohol misuse issues.
* To build and develop long term independent living skills for move on to independent accommodation or longer term supported accommodation.
* Each resident has individual support plans and key work sessions tailored to their needs to enable them to reach their goals and aspirations.
* Residents are supported to manage their own flat and help with budgeting skills and basic life skills.
* Residents are encouraged to attend joint planning about the bigger picture of Petrus and the opportunity to meet other service users within Petrus projects.

The accommodation comprises self-contained flats.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Housing Options Bradford
synopsis: The Housing Options Service provides housing information and advice on a range of housing issues.
description:
The Housing Options Service will work with anyone who is either homeless or threatened with homelessness to try and enable them to stay in their homes or to help them find alternative accommodation. This may include:

- Mediation in landlord and tenant disputes
- Advice and information
- Assistance with housing benefit queries and forms
- Referrals to other agencies for support, mediation and temporary accommodation.

name: Housing Needs Service, Wakefield Council
synopsis: If you are homeless, or think that you are going to become homeless, you can seek advice from Wakefield Council Housing Needs Service
description:
Please contact the Housing Needs Service if you cannot carry on living where you are, and have nowhere else that it is reasonable for you to stay.  Your circumstances will be considered under the homelessness law and advice, support and assistance will be provided to help resolve your homelessness.

Currently the Council's Housing Needs Service can be contacted on 01924 304362 or 304360. The operational hours are:
* Monday to Wednesday 8.30 am to 5.00pm
* Thursday 10.00 am to 5.00 pm
* Friday 8.30 am to 4.30 pm
* Or email on housingneedsservice@wakefield.org.uk

ROUGH SLEEPERS:

If you are rough sleeping in the district, please contact our Rough Sleeper Support Service who will be able to provide assistance that may not be available under duties assessed under the homeless legislation. You can contact Rough Sleepers Outreach Project (Wakefield) - Riverside on: 
* 01924 385722
* Email: RC&S.Wakefield@riverside.org.uk or
* Email: matthew.heald@riverside.org.uk

name: Hosting Project
synopsis: Provides short and medium term accommodation for destitute asylum seekers in volunteers&#39; homes

name: Host Project - Nottingham Arimathea Trust
synopsis: Host provides temporary accommodation for destitute asylum seekers and refugees in the homes of volunteers.
description:
Volunteer hosts provide basic accommodation for an asylum seeker or refugee for between a week and three months, usually in a spare room in their house. We work with partner organisations, including Nottingham and Nottinghamshire Refugee Forum (NNRF), to support our guests and ensure that they can move on from our volunteers' homes to appropriate accommodation.

Our guests must fulfil the following requirements:
- Must be a refugee or an asylum seeker
- Have a definite or prospective move-on date
- The guest must have a designated caseworker 
   throughout their placement.

address.street1: c/o Nottingham and Nottinghamshire Refugee Forum

support.supportInfo: Clients must have a designated caseworker to be eligible for hosting.

name: Hope into Action (various premises)
synopsis: Quality homes for people with multiple issues including those recovering from drug and alcohol addiction, those fleeing domestic violence, street sleepers and those leaving prison.
description:
* We provide all our Clients with a nicely decorated and furnished bedroom for their exclusive use
* We provide gardens. All of our houses have a decent sized garden
* We always try and buy in a decent area of the community away from negative influences
* We provide quality kitchens with all they need to cook, with brand new fridges and appliances etc 

We accept referrals from prisons, hostels, homeless centres, local drug agencies, the Council, churches, the refugee migrant centre or directly from tenants themselves.
You can either call us directly or complete the referral form and return it to us.

accommodation.referralNotes:
We accept referrals from prisons, hostels, homeless centres, local drug agencies, the Council, churches, the refugee migrant centre or directly from tenants themselves. You can either call us directly or complete the referral form and return it to us.

Referral can be downloaded from the website.

features.additionalFeatures:
* Single occupancy rooms only, unless agreed beforehand & based on special circumstances.
* Ground floor rooms catering for limited mobility available, but not wheelchair accessible

* Bedding, toiletries, meals and other items are not provided, but we will work with you and our partners to equip you with anything you need to help you settle into your new home

support.supportInfo:
* It's a move on accommodation with non-judgemental mentoring in order to support you living independently
* You are expected to engage weekly with befriending and mentoring sessions

name: Hope Projects
synopsis: We have 12 houses in Birmingham and the Black Country that are home to over 30 people left homeless and destitute while challenging flawed refusals of asylum.  We cover all utility costs.

name: Hope House
synopsis: Hostel for single men & women
description: Supported short term accommodation for single homeless men and women with support to return to independent living and work

name: Homes of Hope
synopsis: Homes of Hope is a supported housing project for people who are currently without a home, or are at risk of sleeping rough and homelessness. We provide support for residents in a fully furnished shared house for up to two years.
description:
Support is delivered through a weekly programme including:

* Structured recovery programme;
* Therapeutic programme;
* One to one key working;
* Volunteering programme for residents;
* Mentoring;
* Resettlement.

In addition, we aim to use volunteers for supplementary parts of the programme and also work in partnership with other external agencies so that comprehensive support can be delivered to our clients. The requirement for all clients is to work pro-actively with their probation or mental health support workers (or other supporting agencies) and the promotion of return to study / voluntary work and employment schemes

accommodation.referralNotes: We take in referrals from agencies and also individuals may refer themselves. Visit https://www.homesofhope.co.uk/referrals for full referral details and to download the relevant form.

name: Homeground
synopsis: Homeground accommodation comprises of 20 single bedrooms with communal bathroom, kitchen and laundry facilities.
description: Each bedroom is fully furnished with the Homeground providing bed, bedding, wardrobe, chest of drawers, desk, chair, bedside cabinet, storage box and a fridge freezer. Crockery, cutlery and cooking equipment is also provided. Homeground Hostel is located on the 2nd and 3rd floors of a converted building and therefore unfortunately doesn’t offer suitable access for those with mobility needs.

contact.name: Homeground
contact.additionalInfo: You can also send an enquiry on their [Homeground webpage](https://www.localsolutions.org.uk/north-west-services/accommodation-support/2-homeground) which can be found at the bottom of the webpage.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
Free activities on offer at Homeground include watersports (kayaking, windsurfing, canoeing etc,), pool (and games room activities), life skills sessions, careers and jobs drop-in, community allotment, gym and boxing (via Intense Mentoring Service) and football.

FACILITIES -

TV lounge and Pool/games room.
Large conference room and activity room for group activities and events.
Modern, newly refurbished communal kitchen.
Multi-machine laundry room.
Refurbished bath and shower rooms.
Cluster areas with key fob access.
Free Wi-Fi.

support.supportInfo: At Homeground you will be allocated a keyworker and will be issued with a handbook and welcome pack of essential toiletries on induction. Whilst your keyworker will lead on assisting you to develop a support plan, you can access support from any staff member at any time. You are expected to engage in the support process and use your time meaningfully. Homeground provides a number of drop-in services and training opportunities and has additional services on site such Intense Mentoring, DV advice, Benefit Advice and Supported Lodgings. Homeground Hostel is a part of Local Solutions; a Liverpool based charity and social enterprise that provides a wide range of services to people across the region. These services (some described above) are available to everyone at Homeground.

name: Holly House
synopsis: A safe, secure and stable living environment. (14 Beds)
description:
Only accessible via referral: https://theashleyfoundation.org.uk/services/how-to-access-us/

Our staff and volunteers help clients work through their issues and support them in gaining the confidence and stability needed to be able to manage and sustain themselves.

We provide four meals a day with a varied, healthy, and seasonally adjusted menu. Plus we provide options for people who may have any allergies or specific dietary requirements, such as being vegetarian.

Our team of chefs and housekeepers also provide residents with domestic skills training to help prepare them for semi or fully independent living.

More information can be found here: https://theashleyfoundation.org.uk/services/accommodation/

name: Hollins Road
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:

* Hollins Road is a new support accommodation project that aims to equip tenants with the skills, confidence and experience to sustain a tenancy in a shared living environment.
* The project opened in February 2018 and has been designed to meet the needs of people under the age of 35, who have been unable to access their own tenancies due to changes in Housing Benefit legislation.
* The client group has been adversely affected by changes in Housing Benefit eligibility and a lack of available accommodation in the borough.
* Shared accommodation provides routes out of homelessness to younger people whilst providing support to help them adapt to a new way of living.
* Whilst at the scheme tenants will be supported to develop new skills to help them maintain a tenancy. They will learn tenancy management skills, general life skills, employment skills, personal resilience and crisis management. We also help tenants to access suitable training and employment, and support them to go on to find a suitable home to move on to.

Facilities:

* The accommodation comprises of five 2x bedroom flats. 
* Each flat has a shared kitchen, bathroom and living room. 
* The rooms will be furnished and white goods/ cooking utensils will be provided. 
* The project will accommodate 10 x residents in 5x 2 bedroom flats.
* Residents will share with one other tenant. Therefore a willingness to share, co-exist with a flatmate and participate in sharing costs (e.g. electricity) are a key referral requirement. 
* The tenancies will last for a provisional period of 12 months.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation.
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview.
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

synopsis: Temporary supported accommodation for males aged 16 upwards assessed as homeless and referred by City of Edinburgh Council.
description: Temporary supported accommodation for males aged 16 upwards assessed as homeless and referred by City of Edinburgh Council. Specialising in supporting those with mental health and wellbeing and substance misues issues.

synopsis: Temporary supported accommodation for approximately two years for men who have been homeless and have complex needs.
description: Temporary supported accommodation for approximately two years for men who have been homeless and have complex needs. Specialising in supporting those with mental health and wellbeing and substance misuse issues.

synopsis: Supported accommodation for up to two years for women only who have been homeless.
