name: High Peak Homeless Help Emergency Accommodation
synopsis: Emergency Accommodation
description: If you are aged over 16 years, we may be able to find you emergency hosted accommodation in the home of one of our volunteers.  If a host isn’t available we may be able to provide Bed and Breakfast accommodation (one night at a time) or a tent on a secure site. We can also offer tenancy support if you are having problems with rented accommodation.

contact.name: High Peak Homeless Help Emergency Accommodation

accommodation.referralNotes:
If you need help finding accommodation in an emergency please call us on Referral Phone: 07908 008016 or email: hphomelessshelp@yahoo.com. 

Ideally you need to be referred by an agency such as Social Care, Citizen's Advice Bureau, School, Church, GP or Housing Association etc. 

Call us if you're not sure what to do.

name: Hartford Road Hostel
synopsis: 6 bedroom hostel, with shared facilities, garden and support offered by Home Group Support Workers.
description: 6 bedroom hostel, with shared facilities, garden and support offered by Home Group Support Workers.

name: Hampstead Road
synopsis: Supported accommodation
description:
235 Hampstead Road (formerly known as John Dando House) in Great Barr is currently being redeveloped into 31 self contained flats.

There is an IT suite and communal  lounge for the use of residents which encourages interaction between support staff and residents and there is substantial group work activities that take place.

This accommodation is staff 24 hours per day.

name: Greystones Supported Accommodation
synopsis: Greystones provides over 70 units of supported accommodation and support for males over 35.
description: Our core project is a 14 bed unit for men who have issues with alcohol dependency. Many of our residents have complex needs and we provide people with support to help them reduce their alcohol intake and move towards a more independent lifestyle.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals to the project can be made either directly or through the single point of access at Tameside Housing Advice on 0161 331 2700.

name: Greave House
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide accommodation for 11 women and men aged 18 and upwards for an average 12 months period and a crisis unit which is available for 3 men and women for short-term respite, assessment and crisis.

* Each of the 18 residents has individual support plans and key work sessions tailored to their needs to enable them to reach their goals and aspirations.
* Residents are supported to manage their own flat and help with budgeting skills and basic life skills.

The accommodation comprises 2 self contained flats and 16 studio flats with some communal spaces.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Furlong Court
synopsis: Furlong Court offers accommodation and support for people with alcohol and/or substance misuse problems.
description:
Furlong Court provides accommodation for people to address the issues surrounding their addictions, with 24 hour support to help re-build their lives. This includes support with physical and mental health, relationships, training and employment help from trained staff. 

A dedicated support worker will help you to work through your problems and plan for the future. They will also help you to engage with other services.

Furlong Court has an undercroft facility, which features a gym, meeting room, TV lounge and an art room. This communal area provides access to a range of activities, which aim to reduce isolation and offer opportunities for self-improvement and recovery.

You don’t need to be receiving any other type of help or support to access this service.

accommodation.referralNotes: Give us a call on 01782 271014, we will ask you a few questions and arrange for you to come and have a look round so you can decide if Furlong Court is for you.

name: Fleet House
synopsis: Fleet House is a residential and life skills centre for single homeless women aged 16 - 65, with low to medium support needs. Priority is given to applicants with a local connection unless escaping domestic violence.
description:
Fleet House empowers women to make better life choices and tackle the root cause of homelessness to ultimately move on to successfully manage their own home. The scheme has twenty fully furnished rooms arranged into five suites. 

There is a maximum stay of one year. Disabled access is available in one room, including a shower room and adapted kitchen accessible to people using wheelchairs.

accommodation.referralNotes: Fleet House is not a direct access service. We accept referrals from any agency, most referrals come from Bolton&#39;s Homeless Welfare service:&#10;&#10;Bolton Homeless Welfare,&#10;Housing Options and Advice Centre,&#10;1 Silverwell Lane,&#10;Bolton BL1 1QN&#10;&#10;Telephone 01204 335830 or homelesswelfare@bolton.gov.uk&#10;&#10;Monday to Friday 10am to 12.30pm, 1.30pm to 4.30pm, 4pm on Friday.

support.supportInfo:
There is a dedicated team onsite to identify, address and overcome the root cause of homelessness. All residents have bespoke support plans which incorporate the outcomes star, to enable them to work with their support worker and other agencies where appropriate, to address any issues that prevent them from achieving the targets and goal in the support plan.

Alongside structured support sessions, in-house life skills training and educational programmes are in place. These programmes are designed to complement the recovery process by rebuilding confidence and drawing on strengths.

name: Fenland Young People's Project: The Staithe
synopsis: Accommodation and support for young people.
description:
The Fenland Young People's Service (FYPS) provides accommodation and support in Wisbech and March for young people aged 16-25 who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.

FYPS offers:
* A safe, nurturing and empowering environment
* One-to-one support with support staff on site daily and overnight
* Personalised support to achieve your aspirations
* A wide range of fun social activities to get involved in
* Privacy, confidentiality, dignity, independence, choice and personal rights
* Support to make positive changes in your life
* Individual rooms with shared facilities - kitchens, sitting rooms, bathrooms and garden. There is also a small amount of self-contained accommodation for move-on from the hostel

contact.name: Fenland Young People's Project: The Staithe

support.supportInfo: Support is offered around a range of issues including independent living skills, budgeting, access to training, help with family relationships and substance misuse problems.

name: Falinge Road
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide accommodation to Women aged 18 and upwards for up to 12 months high support.
* To support the mental health needs and or drug/alcohol misuse issues.
* To develop independence, encourage self esteem and confidence and encourage appropriate relationship building.
* To encourage active participation in the community.
* Each resident has individual support plans and key work sessions tailored to their needs to enable them to reach their goals and aspirations.
* As part of their support, residents are offered weekly house meeting which enables them to be included in the day to day running and decisions in and around the project.
* Residents are encouraged to attend joint planning about the bigger picture of Petrus and the opportunity to meet other service users within Petrus projects.
* Residents organise events/outings away from their projects.

The accommodation comprises of 10 bedrooms and communal facilities.

accommodation.referralNotes: All referrals and queries should be made by way of the Mental Health Allocation Panel on 01706 654583.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Breakfast and one hot meal per day

name: Faith Lodge
synopsis: Hostel
description:
Faith Lodge is a hostel dedicated to helping men in addiction recovery be that alcohol or non-prescribed/prescribed substance misuse. Refurbished in 2007, Faith Lodge currently houses up to sixteen male residents aged 18 or over.

Staffed 24/7, nights covered by sleeping staff who are contactable in emergencies. In the day staff are at hand to offer resident focused support to help those in the service achieve a life of abstinence of their addiction.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals to the service are accepted via any agency, self, family or friends.

name: FLAGSHIP
synopsis: Supported accommodation for people aged 16-25..
description: Supported accommodation for people aged 16-25 and young families for up to six months in their own "trainer flat" or shared accommodation.

accommodation.referralNotes: Any queries about the referral process can be directed to referrals@flagshipleeds.org.uk.

name: Esther Community
synopsis: Supported accommodation.
description:
Esther Community is a 15 room project for young people. You will be given your own room to stay in, and this will be shown to you during the interview process.

Esther is right in the centre of the city and therefore accessing public transport, shops and facilities can be done with ease.

At the project, we have a social space that has a pool table, darts board and games that you can access. We also have a quiet room that can be used to access the computer or to watch a DVD if you wish.

There is a garden at the rear which is used for communal barbeques in the summer, gardening activities and as somewhere to enjoy the sun!

There is a communal kitchen for you to prepare food and we also run cookery classes and occasional group meals which is a great way for you all to get to know each other and enjoy a sense of community.

During your stay at Esther, you will be assigned a Keyworker who will work with you to identify the areas that you may need support with. Their aim is to equip you with the necessary skills to move on and to address any difficulties you may be having that you wish to have support with.

Our Structured Day Plan allows those staying at the project to engage with activities. These activities can range from educational courses such as literacy or numeracy to group activities where those living at the project can be creative or learn new skills. Part of the aim of the Structured Day Plan is to build confidence in those individuals who often feel marginalised as a result of their experiences.  Young people staying at the project are able to become a part of this planning by suggesting what activities may appeal to them or what skills they may wish to learn or improve.

The Structured Day Plan also offers residents a chance to get together and feel a real sense of belonging to a community. We have been able to offer such activities as mosaic making, group cooking and card making. Many residents have remarked how much they have not only enjoyed the activity but also enjoyed the sense of community that this has brought to the house

accommodation.referralNotes: We accept referrals through the Homeless Prevention Panel and it is also possible to complete a self-referral. Please visit http://esthercommunity.org.uk/referrals.php for more information and a referral form.

name: Erewash Teenage Parents Service
synopsis: Erewash Teenage Parents Service
description: The Erewash Teenage Parents Service offers accommodation and support to pregnant women and parents, normally aged between 16 and 25.

features.additionalFeatures: There are 8 houses across Long Eaton and Ilkeston for sole occupancy.

name: Endeavour House
synopsis: Accommodation for homeless people.
description: A modern lifehouse containing single rooms for individuals experiencing homelessness with support services delivered by a partner managing agent in a residential location.

contact.name: Manchester City Council
contact.additionalInfo: This property is allocated through Manchester City Council's housing register - Manchester Move. To register your interest, please make contact with Manchester City Council.

accommodation.referralNotes: To register your interest in this property, please make contact with Manchester City Council.

name: Emmaus Salford
synopsis: Residential community.
description:
Emmaus is not emergency accommodation or a hostel. We are a residential community where people who have experienced homelessness can make it their home, work in a social enterprise, gain confidence, and get access to the support needed to live independently again. We call these people companions.

To join an Emmaus community, companions work full time collecting and reselling donated furniture. This work supports the Community financially and enables companions to develop skills, rebuild their self-respect and help others in greater need.

A wide range of help is on hand for our companions, covering anything from personal development, to training and career development.

The community is a drug and alcohol free environment and we also have access to alcohol and drugs support.

accommodation.referralNotes:
An individual can apply directly to the Community Manager to request a place in the Community but if they are already living in a hostel or are perhaps sleeping rough but in contact with a referring organisation we ask that organisation to make the application for them. 

If your organisation would like to refer someone to the Emmaus Community with a request for their admission as a Companion you will be asked to fill in a confidential referral form and post or email it back. If you use email please write 'referral' and the applicant's name in the email header. 

If you, or someone you know, may benefit from being part of the Emmaus Salford community, please complete our referral form, email us or call 0161 737 8279.

support.supportInfo: On joining us, everyone must agree to: &#10;* Volunteer for up to 40 hours per week within Emmaus&#10;* If you are in receipt of state benefits you MUST sign off these immediately &#10;* Abide by the rule of no drugs or alcohol in the Emmaus community&#10;* Respect yourself and other people and the community &#10;&#10;The offer: &#10;We provide each companion their own bedroom, shared amenities, communal lounge/diner and other large communal lounge, three meals a day prepared Monday to Friday and plenty of prepared meals to help yourself to over the weekend, toiletries, work clothes, training, and a weekly allowance of &pound;40. Companions receive guidance and support to identify their own needs: setting aims and objectives to promote personal development, gain new skills, and grow confidence. We support companions to pursue adult education courses, to build their qualifications, to increase their employment opportunities, and to develop their CV for the time when they choose to leave Emmaus.

support.supportInfo:

* Volunteer for up to 40 hours per week within Emmaus
* If you are in receipt of state benefits you MUST sign off these immediately 
* Abide by the rule of no drugs or alcohol in the Emmaus community
* Respect yourself and other people and the community 

The offer: 
We provide each companion their own bedroom, shared amenities, communal lounge/diner and other large communal lounge, three meals a day prepared Monday to Friday and plenty of prepared meals to help yourself to over the weekend, toiletries, work clothes, training, and a weekly allowance of £40. Companions receive guidance and support to identify their own needs: setting aims and objectives to promote personal development, gain new skills, and grow confidence. We support companions to pursue adult education courses, to build their qualifications, to increase their employment opportunities, and to develop their CV for the time when they choose to leave Emmaus.

name: Emmaus - Binley
synopsis: Space for 17 people at our community accommodation in Binley, Coventry.
description:
At Emmaus Coventry & Warwickshire, formerly homeless people and people at risk of homelessness find a place where they can enjoy companionship and support.

We offer a home
We currently have space to accommodate 17 people at our accommodation in Binley, Coventry. Everyone has their own bedroom whilst living in the community, as well as many large communal areas where they can socialise.

We offer a new beginning
Emmaus offers homeless people a fresh start in life with the support of the community around them. They can stay as long as they wish and are offered opportunities to acquire skills. Some stay for only a few months in order to get themselves back on their feet before returning to independent living, but for others Emmaus will become their permanent home. If a companion wants to move on, he or she will be assisted to find accommodation and work.

name: Elm House
synopsis: A safe, secure and stable living environment. (28 Beds)
description:
Only accessible via referral: https://theashleyfoundation.org.uk/services/how-to-access-us/

Our staff and volunteers help clients work through their issues and support them in gaining the confidence and stability needed to be able to manage and sustain themselves.

We provide four meals a day with a varied, healthy, and seasonally adjusted menu. Plus we provide options for people who may have any allergies or specific dietary requirements, such as being vegetarian.

Our team of chefs and housekeepers also provide residents with domestic skills training to help prepare them for semi or fully independent living.

More information can be found here: https://theashleyfoundation.org.uk/services/accommodation/

name: Elizabeth Anderson House (Liverpool)
synopsis: Accommodation for single, teenage parents aged 16 to 25 years
description:
Elizabeth Anderson House was originally a very large house that was first converted into 12 bedsits and then later into five, two bedroom self-contained flats for single, teenage parents aged 16 to 25 years. Each family has their own fully furnished flat and access to a communal lounge and a garden where children can play.

Staff offer support around managing money, preparing healthy meals, claiming welfare benefits, accessing training, education or employment.

The building is situated close to bus routes, shops, nurseries and schools.

Parents can stay for up to 2 years and are supported to move to their own independent property. The average stay is about 14 months

To be eligible for housing at the scheme you need to be male or female:

- aged between 16 and 25
- have a child or be in your 3rd trimester of pregnancy
- be from the Liverpool area
- need accommodation and support to be able to live independently with your child(ren).

We accept referrals from:
- Midwives
- Family nurses
- Social workers
- any organisation that comes into contact with a teenage or young parent (such as solicitors, etc.)
- the parent(s) themselves
- a family member of the parent.

accommodation.referralNotes: You can complete an on-line application form [here](https://www.shap.org.uk/housing-application-form/) or download the form [here](https://www.shap.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Housing-Application-Form-124F-1.docx) and email it to **cbu@shap.org.uk**.

name: East Adam Street Resettlement Flats
synopsis: We offer a safe, supportive environment for individuals, helping them make positive choices about their current circumstances.
description: East Adam Street provides a stable, secure temporary accommodation option for homeless people in Edinburgh.  Support is available on site and at The Pleasance Lifehouse, which is staffed 24/7 .

accommodation.referralNotes:
Our service is intended for anyone identified as a homeless person with entitlement to accommodation from the City of Edinburgh Council.  

Referral is available initially to those in the Rapid Access Accommodation provision (including The Pleasance) and then to other Temporary Accommodation providers in Edinburgh.

name: Dunstable Stage One
synopsis: We have properties in Dunstable and Houghton Regis which provide short-term accommodation for single homeless people, of any gender, aged 16 and over.

accommodation.referralNotes: Apply for temporary supported housing by completing this application form - https://www.signpostsso.org/application-form.

name: Dunedin Harbour Hostel
synopsis: Dunedin Harbour hostel offers residents a pathway out of homelessness.
description:
When service users arrive at Dunedin Harbour they will be given a key worker who will offer support at every step.

This includes help with addiction issues, mental health, finding work and support to find a permanent home. We offer residents a range of activities, including gym groups, football sessions, cooking classes and alternative therapy sessions.

Service users create a specialised support plan which is monitored and reviewed regularly. Staff also signpost service users to external agencies depending on their individual need.

[Check out this video featuring service users and staff from our gym group.](https://youtu.be/2bD7zm7seZ4)

### The next steps:
Service users have three options when they feel ready to move on:

#### Supported flats: 
Our hostel has six self-contained supported flats at the back for single people or couples. The flats allows residents to receive support from hostel staff while living more independently. The supported flats are designed to help people make the transition from living in the Harbour to getting their own home. 

#### Resettlement flats: 
Service users who want to move into their own home but feel they need a little more time can use one of our 10 resettlement flats at Westfield Avenue in Edinburgh. A dedicated resettlement worker is available to offer additional support. When residents feel ready, they can apply for a permanent tenancy.

#### Permanent tenancy:
Dunedin Harbour has a nomination arrangement which allows direct access into Dunedin Canmore mainstream tenancies should a service user's stay in the resettlement flats prove successful.

accommodation.referralNotes:
Referrals to Dunedin Harbour are made through the [homeless team at City of Edinburgh Council](http://www.edinburgh.gov.uk/info/20125/homeless_or_at_risk).

The council identifies people who need supported accommodation. You can ask to be moved to Dunedin Harbour, but it depends on availability.

If the Harbour is full, you can ask for your details to be held by Dunedin Harbour and we'll contact you when we have a space.

name: Dispersed Properties (YMCA Liverpool)
synopsis: Dispersed properties currently consist of 31 self contained flats, which consist of one bedroom, one kitchen, one living area and one bathroom.
description: All our flats are fully furnished and decorated to a high standard. Residents are responsible for providing their own kettle, toaster, crockery, cutlery and bedding. 2. In all buildings, there are no lifts indoors. To gain access to some of the properties there are steps outside so they will not be suitable for disabled wheelchair access.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via https://liverpool.gov.uk/housing/homeless-or-at-risk/

features.additionalFeatures: All properties have basic furnishings and white good are supplied.

support.supportInfo:
We provide temporary accommodation with support for up to 12 months. Once accepted onto the Dispersed service, you will be allocated a Support Worker. You will be required to complete the Outcome Star which highlights your support needs. Following this, you will be required to engage with your Support Worker on a weekly basis where you will address your individual needs. You will also be referred and encouraged to attend an appointment with our YMCA Learning and Development Officers to discuss training opportunities. On a weekly basis, you will need to be actively bidding on Property Pool Plus. Typical areas of support include welfare benefits, rent, council tax issues, budgeting, managing tenancy, social isolation, education/employment and training, mental health.

Staff

We currently have 3 full time Support Workers. Support workers work 7.30am – 3.30pm Monday to Friday and 1 weekend in 4 is currently covered.

name: Discovery House - Bradford
synopsis: Discovery House provides short-term emergency accommodation.
description:
We support new and entrenched rough sleepers. We fast-track assessments to identify individual solutions to each client’s homelessness.

The scheme offers a range of accommodation; 

•	8 rooms for clients who have slept rough for less than six months, 2 rooms for ‘entrenched’ rough sleepers
•	7 beds for clients with no recourse to public funds (2 beds dedicated for females)
•	An additional 10 ‘sit-up’ spaces during cold weather

name: Discovery House
synopsis: Accommodation for homeless people.
description: A modern lifehouse containing single rooms for individuals experiencing homelessness with support services delivered by a partner managing agent in a city centre location.

contact.name: Manchester City Council
contact.additionalInfo: This property is allocated through Manchester City Council's housing register - Manchester Move. To register your interest, please make contact with Manchester City Council.

accommodation.referralNotes: To register your interest in this property, please make contact with Manchester City Council.

name: Davitt House
synopsis: Detached stone property in Headingley
description:
Davitt House is a detached stone property in Headingley which contains 10 one bedroom bedsit/flats. The main house contains 7 units and the recently refurbished attached cottage has been converted to include 3 units. The House is a grade II listed and is set within beautiful grounds.

We also manage housing association properties and currently have 38 flats. Our properties are mainly located in the LS7 & LS8 areas of Leeds – Harehills, Chapeltown and Chapel Allerton. Most of the properties are for over 55’s and some are in sheltered accommodation schemes.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you feel you would like to be placed on our waiting list, contact our office and ask to speak to Vicky Annable who is our Support Worker. You will be asked for your contact details and an appointment will be arranged for you to come to our office for a housing assessment.

name: Darbyshire House
synopsis: Darbyshire House offers short term accommodation for females and males aged 16+.
description: The service provides 45 bed spaces for people aged 16 or over. 40 of which are half board and the other 5 are resettlement flats. The service is catered however; there are catering facilities which enable service users to cook for themselves should they wish to. The service is a bus ride away from the centre of Liverpool, and has an excellent bus service. Within walking distance from the centre the following facilities are available: The One Stop Shop /Job Centre/Opticians /Dentist & Doctors.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
Darbyshire House has a full time Employment coordinator based in the onsite training room where service users have access to IT equipment as well as support to access training, gain work experience and getting work ready. 

There is also a multi Faith room where residents can use for quiet times and reflection.

A Visitors room is available for planned visits with family and children. 

Darbyshire House hold courses within the centre including a Skills for Life Programme and also offers access to additional local courses including; Arts and Crafts, Printmaking, Drama, Performing Arts, Music, Plastering, Room Renovations, ESOL, Literacy, Creative Writing, Numeracy, Information Technology. Service User involvement is encouraged at Darbyshire House and there are various committees and groups including Resident Committee, Equality & Diversity Group and Safeguarding Group.

support.supportInfo: Trained staff adopt a person centred approach and enable service users to identify and address their needs in order to move forward successfully. This is undertaken through encouragement, activities and regular support meetings, where service users are able to address their wellbeing, self esteem, spirituality, addictions and mental health in a safe environment.

name: Cyrenians Coventry
synopsis: Housing Association
description: Coventry Cyrenians provides temporary supported accommodation for single adults aged 16+ who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. Their fully furnished shared houses across Coventry and Warwickshire offer a safe and supportive environment. Residents receive tailored support to develop life skills, access training or employment, manage finances, and prepare for independent living. Some female-only housing is available

accommodation.referralNotes:
To apply, complete the [referral form on their website](https://coventrycyrenians.co.uk/get-help/referral-form/) or contact the team

Find out more about the accommodation offer on their [website](https://coventrycyrenians.co.uk/about-us/our-homes/)

name: Cunningham House
synopsis: Safe and supportive hostel accommodation for homeless adults in Edinburgh.
description:
Cunningham House has 23 rooms, 20 for men and 3 for women. It’s a supported hostel, which means you have your own room and self-catering facilities, but you can also access support while you get your life back on track.

You can stay at Cunningham House initially for up to 2 years. During this time you will be supported by a key worker who will work with you to draw up a personal support plan. This will outline your goals and identify the support you’ll need to achieve them.

We can support you with:

- basic living skills
- budgeting
- addressing the issues that led to you being homeless
- finding permanent accommodation
- any other issues you wish to address

accommodation.referralNotes: Call us on 0131 225 4795

features.additionalFeatures: WIFI & Computer Access

name: Creative Support
synopsis: Support for adults over the age of 16, who are living in North Liverpool and at risk of becoming homeless.
description:
#### Our service covers the following postcodes: ####
Part of L4 and L13, L9, 10, 11, 12, 14 and 28.

#### We can provide support to the following groups: ####
* People with mental health needs
* People with substance misuse issues
* People with a history of offending
* Homeless families with support needs
* Single homeless people with support needs
* Victims of domestic abuse
* Veterans
* People with long term health conditions
* Refugees

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals can be made through the person calling into the office at **0151 556 7629** or via the referral form on the website which can be found [here](https://www.thelivewelldirectory.com/Documents/Download/244/Liverpool-Housing-Su).

support.supportInfo:
#### Free advice service (appointment only) ####
* County Road children's centre.  Monday 13:00 to 16:00  (0151 233 3760)
* Clubmoor children's centre.  Wednesday 13:00 to 16:00 (0151 233 5800)
* Yew tree children's centre.  Thursday 10:30 to 12:30  (0151 296 7950)

Our support staff can provide assistance with:
* Budgeting and debt management
* Filling in forms
* Accessing benefits
* Finding accommodation
* Help to sustain your accommodation
* Building confidence and working to improve mental and physical wellbeing

name: Coppice
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide low level support accommodation for 6 single men aged 18 and upwards. The length of stay is determined by Petrus.
* Residents are supported to manage the accommodation and help them with budgeting skills.
* As part of their support, residents are offered weekly house meetings which enables them to be included in the day-to-day running and decisions in and around the project.
* To support the mental health and or drug/alcohol misuse issues.
* To build and develop long term independent living skills for move on to independent accommodation or longer term supported accommodation.

The accommodation comprises 6 bedrooms and communal facilities.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Contact Hostel
synopsis: Accommodation for young women
description:
Contact is a charity providing accommodation and practical  support for homeless teenage girls (aged 16 – 19) from the Manchester area.

We have 8 bedrooms, offering a welcoming and homely atmosphere in the heart of South Manchester. We also help young women with the next stage, whether they want to return to education, start a job or explore training opportunities.

accommodation.referralNotes:
All referrals to Contact are made through Centrepoint.

Phone: 0161 228 7654

Centrepoint opening times: 
Mon-Fri: 10am-4.30pm
Apart from Weds: 10am-12.30pm

Once we have received your completed application from Centrepoint you will be asked to attend an interview at Contact.
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Contact provides breakfast and Sunday lunch

features.additionalFeatures:
**Can I stay out? How many nights?**

You can stay out a maximum of 3 nights in a week.

Tell staff when you are going out and tell them if you are staying out.

This is important because if there was a fire, no one would know if you were in and someone might get hurt looking for you.

If there is no contact from you for 48 hours we will phone the police and report you missing!

**Can I have visitors?**

The official time for visiting in on a Saturday from 11am to 10.30pm and is at the discretion of the staff on duty. The staff on duty retains the right to refuse a visitor onto the premises and also to request them to leave at any time. Visitors must be over 16 and female

name: Complex Needs Service, Rochdale (Redfearn House)
synopsis: Redfearn House offers supported accommodation for single people with high-level support needs aged 18 and over, who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, and have a history of offending and substance misuse.
description:
The service consists of 16 self-contained fully furnished flats in a grouped accommodation setting at Redfearn House with communal facilities including garden, laundry, trainer kitchen, meeting room, and access to IT. We also offer another 15 independent properties dispersed within the community

Our staff based at Redfearn House are available 24/7, working with clients on a one-to-one basis to deliver a package of support that is specific to individual needs. Staff specialise in delivering housing-related support but will work with a variety of specialist service providers in order to deliver a coordinated approach for people who have additional support needs.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals to the scheme can be made by requesting a referral form from our Central Referral Team via email. Once a completed referral form is received, we will arrange a Needs Assessment interview with the applicant; if they meet the criteria they will be placed on the waiting list for service.

support.supportInfo:
At the move-in stage, the allocated Resettlement Worker will complete an induction programme with each new client. Following this, they will arrange an appointment with the client to agree upon a support plan, which is devised and agreed with the client, Resettlement Worker and any other agencies that the clients would like to be involved.

Support that can be offered, include:

Advice on housing rights and responsibilities.
Support to develop the skills and capacity needed to meet their obligations as a tenant.
Support accessing specialist agencies e.g. mental health and substance misuse issues.
Support in applying for benefits, grants and loans (including help with forms).
Support to assist individuals with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts etc.
Joint Working with specialist support services/agencies.
Support in accessing employment, voluntary work opportunities, training and education.
Help building self-confidence.
Support to develop independent living skills, including in a shared environment.
Help to access and maintain suitable long-term accommodation when the client is ready to move on.

name: Cheviot House
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide low support accommodation for 6 single woman and men. Length of stay is determined by Petrus.
* To support the mental health and or drug/alcohol misuse issues.
* To build and develop long term independent living skills for move on to independent accommodation or longer term supported accommodation.
* Each resident has individual support plans and key work sessions tailored to their needs to enable them to reach their goals and aspirations.
* Residents are supported to manage their own flat and help with budgeting skills and basic life skills.
* Residents are encouraged to attend joint planning about the bigger picture of Petrus and the opportunity to meet other service users within Petrus projects.

The accommodation comprises self-contained flats.

accommodation.referralNotes:
* We accept self-referrals and referrals made by any statutory or voluntary agency, or individual on behalf of the person who is need of accommodation. 
* An interview will usually be conducted by a Project Leader and usually at least one Assistant Project Leader. The interview recording form goes into more detail asking the person to expand on previous housing, be more specific about their mental health, drug and or alcohol usage, benefits, medication, debts, interests and their expectations of high supported accommodation. There is always an opportunity for people to ask us questions at the end of the interview. 
* The referring agency should, wherever possible, arrange for a staff member to attend the interview with the referee and provide any information that will assist us with our risk assessment before the interview; for example any risk assessments completed by the Probation Service. This will not necessarily hinder acceptance to the project and will be treated in the strictest confidence. All appropriate questions can be found on the referral details forms.
* For an application form and further information, please visit https://www.petrus.org.uk/housing_referral.php.

name: Chatterton Hey House
synopsis: Chatterton Hey House is a registered care home for adult male offenders and those at risk of offending.
description:
We are part of the Langley House Trust, a care provider with a history of helping to rehabilitate young adults who may have a disability or history of substance misuse.

We offer rooms both on a full-board and self-catering basis. We have ground floor rooms available and some are accessible for wheelchair users with specially adapted facilities for people with disabilities.

accommodation.referralNotes: Exclusions apply to Chatterton Hey, please contact our referrals team for more information: referrals@langleyhousetrust.org

features.additionalFeatures:
We have extensive grounds (including gardening projects and farm animals), a computer room, televisions in the rooms, internet access for residents.

We also have independent move-on accommodation on-site (Heaton House – a self-contained 3 bed house in the grounds of Chatterton Hey).

support.supportInfo:
With quality and person-centred care, professionals can make a real impact, helping adults to become active in community life, to become more independent and seek employment.

We offer a high level of care including a forensic step-down service, extra care facilities for individuals with health care needs (including a clinical team comprising of psychiatrist, psychologist, carers and addiction counsellors), an in-house clinician, access to the Langley Academy and a wide range of activities including links to voluntary work.

name: Carters Green / Western Gateway
synopsis: Supported accommodation
description:
Our flagship Western Gateway development in Carters Green is our main housing site in Sandwell.

Western Gateway comprises 96 self contained units of accommodation, Cielo Coffee, YGym, youth zone and training area.

name: Canaan Trust
synopsis: The Trust operates two houses in Long Eaton collectively providing 12 places for homeless males 18 - 70+.
description:
The Trust's hostels provide SUPPORTED ACCOMMODATION which entails a package of support and programmes designed to assist each individual to address their often complex needs with the aim of achieving independent living back in the Community.
Clients are expected to engage with the programme which provides help with an extensive range of Life Skills and Employability Skills as well as providing individually tailored support to help address the individual's personal issues.

name: CHS Young Parent Project
synopsis: The Young Parent Project provides accommodation and support for young parents aged 16-25 who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.
description:
* Please visit [our website](https://www.chsgroup.org.uk/coronavirus-update/) for covid 19 updates.

At Young Parent Project in Cambridge we provide accommodation and support for young parents aged 16-25 who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.

Young Parents are either expecting a baby (at least 6 months pregnant) or have a baby aged less than 12 months.

**Young Parent Project offers**

* One to one support from a team with lots of experience of supporting young parents
* A safe, nurturing and empowering environment
* Support to achieve individual aspirations
* Support staff on site Monday-Friday and an emergency call point to speak to an advisor at other times
* A wide range of fun social activities to get involved in with your baby
* Opportunities to learn about child care and development, including baby first aid and regular drop-ins from the health visitor
* A subsidised place for your baby at Sunflower Nursery, located below the Young Parent Project
* 8 self-contained studio flats with bedroom for baby, kitchen/diner and bathroom
* Wi-Fi

You can apply [here](https://www.chsgroup.org.uk/supported-housing/young-people/young-parents/)

accommodation.referralNotes: You can apply [here](https://www.chsgroup.org.uk/supported-housing/young-people/young-parents/)

name: Bury Supported Housing
synopsis: We provide tenancy related supported housing within the Bury area. We provide emotional and practical support, offering fully furnished accommodation in partnership with other housing associations.
description:
* Every individual is allocated a support worker who helps them work towards goals with the aim of becoming more independent within the community and sustaining their tenancy.
* When individuals are ready to move on to more independent living, we provide support to achieve this and attain a general needs tenancy.
* We work with individuals on a one to one basis to assess their mental health and housing needs and then offer appropriate support based on this.
* We actively involve tenants in the running of our supported housing scheme.
* We also offer a personal assistant service to those in receipt of Individual Budgets/Direct Payments.
* Our team of support workers are available Monday-Friday and we also operate an out-of-hours emergency support system.

accommodation.referralNotes: All applications should be made via the central access point based at the Town Hall on 0161 253 5940. This should be accompanied by a copy of an up-to-date risk assessment from the community mental health trust. We’ll then hold a meeting with the individual and their care co-ordinator/referring agency to discuss their options with us.

name: Bradford Nightstop
synopsis: Emergency Accommodation and Extended Stays for 16-25 year olds in the homes of trained and vetted volunteers across the Bradford district.
description:
Bradford Nightstop provides emergency accommodation for homeless young people (16-25) in the homes of vetted and trained volunteers. One night at a time, the young person is offered a place of safety with a room of their own, transport, meals, essential supplies, washing facilities and support for their next step.

Nightstop does not accept self-referrals so you must be referred from places such as Culture Fusion, Housing Options or Trafalgar House Police Station in Bradford. In Keighley, you can be referred from Keighley Police Station or at the Town Hall.

Nightstop will arrange transportation to the host's home either by a taxi (female driver available) or by one of our volunteer drivers (male and female available). If you have nowhere safe to wait before being picked up, Nightstop can arrange Safe Waiting either at Trafalgar Police Station, Bradford Community Radio, Carlisle Business Centre or at the home of one of our volunteers.

name: Bournemouth Domestic Abuse Service
synopsis: Bournemouth Women&#39;s Refuge consists of 18 spaces for Women and their Children. Support is provided for up to six months. There are 2 self contained flats, the rest have shared facilities. The Refuge is staffed from 8:00am to 10.30pm Monday to Friday and 9:00am to 4:30pm Saturday &amp; Sunday. Support outside of these times is provided by New Leaf&#10;Support Solutions using assistive technologies.
description:
Service Users shall be eligible for this Service if they meet the following criteria:
· Any woman who has been subjected to any form of Domestic Abuse, including Sexual, Financial, Emotional or Physical abuse shall be eligible for the service.
· The applicant must have recourse to public funds, or be able to financially support themselves and dependants or be eligible for the Destitute Domestic Violence Concession for Housing Benefit under immigration rules.

Exclusions to the above are assessed on a case-by-case basis.

accommodation.referralNotes: If you are rough sleeping or at risk of rough sleeping, please contact Excel Housing Solutions [here](http://www.excelhousingsolutions.com/contact/) and they can provide you with information of services that can assist you.

name: Blackpool Supported Housing (Making Space)
synopsis: Our Blackpool, Fylde and Wyre supported housing services combine accommodation with varying levels of care and support, giving you a place of your own and a real sense of independence.
description:
Depending on your requirements, we have different types of supported housing and supported living services available to you.

All of our services have a qualified team of professionals around to provide you with the care and support you need. This includes short-term, long-term and temporary accommodation in case of an emergency. 

This combination of housing and personalised support is ideal for people with mental health conditions and learning disabilities, for older people and for those living with dementia, who want to have their own independence but the assurance of a care package suited to their requirements. 

-IMPORTANT NOTE-

The location listed here is simply for the offices where you must go to arrange the accommodation, not the location of the accommodation itself.

name: Birchwood Nursing Home
synopsis: Supported accommodation for people with mental health problems,
description: Birchwood is a registered nursing home that provides single en-suite accommodation for sixteen men and women with enduring mental health problems. Birchwood works towards enabling the individual to gain the most out of their lives by reintroducing and maintaining daily living skills, increasing confidence, maximising independence and maintaining health.

accommodation.referralNotes: For more information or to make a referral or self referral, please contact us.

name: Beswicke Royds Street
synopsis: Petrus aim to accommodate people who are homeless or would otherwise be at risk of homelessness and who are in need of and accepting of support in their transition to independent living.
description:
Project Aims:
* To provide accommodation for 15 service users aged 18 and upwards for 12 month period.
* To provide accommodation for people with multiple chronic needs, for people with a diagnosed mental health issues and/or secondary issues such as alcohol/substance misuse.
* To operate a high quality supported accommodation project that meets the basic needs of residents.
* To assist residents and the wider community to take part in group activities and advice sessions which promote personal well-being and independent living skills.
* Each resident has key working sessions tailored to their needs using client dial indicators.
* Areas of need are identified and support plans are structured to meet residents needs.
* As part of their support, residents participate in house meetings and take part in structured activities with Petrus Incredible Edible Rochdale (formerly Green Gym) and at the Petrus Hub.

The accommodation comprises 3 self-contained flats and 12 bedrooms plus communal living space.

accommodation.referralNotes: All referrals and queries should be made by way of the Mental Health Allocation Panel on 01706 654583.

name: Belvidere Family Centre
synopsis: Emergency 24-hour supported accommodation for homeless families
description:
The Belvidere Family Centre provides self-contained apartments with private bathrooms and kitchens for 16 homeless families and a wide range of communal facilities (including laundry and communal meeting rooms) to help them rebuild their lives.  There is a large garden at the rear of the building and a play area for young children.   It is close to amenities such as bus routes, schools and supermarkets.

This emergency accommodation is made available for a temporary period only, following assessment by Liverpool City Council’s Housing Options Service.  The average length of stay is about 10 weeks.

You will be allocated a named key-worker who will be responsible for helping you find permanent accommodation, register on Property Pool and ensuring you are able to claim and maintain any benefits that you are entitled to.  You do not need to be on benefits to be referred to the service.

Whilst residing at Belvidere Family Centre we can support you to:

- identify any barriers to may have being rehoused such as  rent arrears, anti-social behaviour, etc
- develop independent living skills
- explore the full range of appropriate and realistic housing options that are available to you
- register on Liverpool’s property pool system
- make appropriate and realistic bids for properties
- understand the facilities in the local area and to research the area in which you would choose to move
- prepare for the transition to independence and permanent housing.

accommodation.referralNotes:
It is only possible to access the family centre by referral from Liverpool City Council's Housing Options Service. They can be contacted by calling into any One Stop Shop or by phoning Careline on **0151 233 3800**
(freephone 0800 731 6844).

name: Belmont Drive Supported Housing Project
synopsis: The Belmont Drive Project is supported housing accommodation for single homeless people who have a range of high risk / high needs.
description:
The service consists of 11 fully furnished one bedroom self-contained flats, newly refurbished to a high standard. Laundry facilities are provided with washer, dryer, iron and vacuum cleaner. All new residents will be provided with a starter pack including bedding, crockery, cutlery, pans, toiletry bag and a food parcel. Weekend communal breakfast meals are provided. 

Tenants are supported to manage their tenancy and work towards building the life skills required to live independently.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk
accommodation.availabilityOfMeals: Weekend breakfast is provided free of charge to give tenants a chance to socialise with other tenants and staff on-duty.

features.additionalFeatures:
Tenants living within Belmont Drive can benefit from a range of activities run on-site by the staff team, and from outside agencies who visit the project. These activities are:

* Tenancy Ready resettlement programme available on-site, and sessions are also delivered via Crisis.
* Benefit maximise assessments,
* Budging plans,
* Cooking on a budget,
* Breakfast club (food and social meeting),
* Current affairs morning sessions,
* Gardening / fishing projects,
* Men’s Health & wellbeing Groups,
* Women health & wellbeing groups,
* Creative workshop,
* Mindfulness session,
* Culture / educational trips,
* Physical activity programs,
* Film & popcorn nights,

Belmont drive also links in with:
* Crisis Skylights Timetable of activities and events.  
* Learning centres in the local community accessing employment and training opportunities. 
* All tenants can also access the involvement opportunities at Liverpool YMCA, Leeds Start, and vice-versa.

The Belmont Drive Project has a multi-functional meeting room on-site for both staff and tenants to access for 1:1 meetings, group sessions and activities work. The building is fully secured with CCTV and a dorr entry system.

support.supportInfo:
Tenants will be allocated a main Keyworker, and also a secondary keyworker (who will support the case if the main keyworker is unavailable). Support sessions will take place on a weekly basis, and will be booked in-advance with the tenant. All tenants are required to engage with their Keyworkers as part of the Licence Agreement. Individual support packages will be put in to place with full risk assessment to create a safe environment for the tenants who reside in the service and the staff team. Clear and realistic support plans will be put in to place with achievable goals in various areas, to work towards potential move-on options available and progressing towards with the tenancy ready resettlement.

The operational staff team consists of a Project Manager, 2 daytime Keyworkers and 3 evening and weekend Support Staff. The service also has a Senior Business Support Officer, and the project is fully supported by a team of in-house Welfare Benefit specialists.

name: B4N - Reading's Winter Night Shelter
synopsis: Reading Churches Winter Night Shelter
description:
COVID UPDATE

Due to the pandemic, B4N is closed this winter - alternative self-contained provisions are in place from central government funding.
______________________________________________

Reading Churches Winter Night Shelter - Nightly accommodation, meals and referrals to Homelessness Support Services and St. Mungo's (Rough Sleeper Outreach Service)

name: Ashburn House
synopsis: Ashburn House offers supported accommodation to single males aged 16-65 who have a local connection with Rochdale and who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.
description:
The project consists of 8 one bedroom flats for single occupancy (for up to 12 months) and 4 flats used as Emergency and Assessment units (for up to 8 weeks). It also offers communal facilities including garden, meeting room and I.T access.

All applicants for the adult care funded flats need to be able to demonstrate a local connection with Rochdale. There are additional flats that are available for single people aged 16 and over who need low-level assistance for the long-term.

accommodation.referralNotes:
Referrals to the Adult Care beds must be made through the Central Access Information and Assessment Service which is operated by Shelter on behalf of Rochdale MBC. Shelter can be contacted on 0344 515 1850 or via e-mail at centralaccess@shelter.org.uk
 
To refer to the low-level beds, please contact our Central Referral Team on 01706 646922 or crt@stepping-stone.org.uk

support.supportInfo: Staff at the project work with clients on a one to one basis to deliver a package of support that is specific to individual needs. Examples of Support that can be offered include: help accessing and maintaining suitable long term accommodation, advice on housing right and responsibilities, help accessing specialist agencies around mental health issues, help accessing specialist services around substance/alcohol issues, help with applying for benefits, grants and loans, help with budgeting, paying bills and managing debts, help filling in forms, support accessing specialist agencies and support services, support in accessing employment, voluntary work opportunities, training and education, help building self confidence and support to develop shared living skills

name: Anne Conway House
synopsis: Anne Conway House provides short stay supported housing for single homeless males or females aged 16+.
description:
Anne Conway House is a purpose built building with 13 individual resident rooms.

It also has one flat which is fully accessible for a disabled person. There is level access to Anne Conway house and there is a lift within the building.

Starter packs are given during your induction. These contain bedding, crockery, cutlery and pots and pans.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures: Other facilities include a communal garden with decking area and IT facilities.

support.supportInfo:
We provide psychologically informed support and accommodation for people with complex needs. The intensive support we offer is rooted in the principles of Trauma Informed Care and Cognitive Analytic Therapy.

We also work closely with external partners to ensure that additional support is accessed in a flexible, meaningful and person centred way.

On acceptance into the Support and Accommodation Service you will receive a full induction and will be introduced to your key worker and other members of the support team. We will work with you to understand you situation and the things you would like to work towards.

We offer support with improving your life skills, maximising your income, participating in education and training opportunities, accessing employment opportunities and health services, exploring issues around your race and identity, accessing appropriate specialist support services and local social support networks, preparing for independent living and securing appropriate move-on accommodation.

name: Ann Fowler House
synopsis: Ann Fowler House is a hostel for females and males aged 16+.
description: Ann Fowler House offers short term accommodation for those in housing need. Situated in the centre of Liverpool near Lime Street Station the service provides 38 bed spaces, including two ground floor rooms for people with disabilities, for people aged 16 or over. All other bed spaces are accessed via stairs. Out of the 38 beds 30 beds are half board and 8 are self catered.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
Ann Fowler House hold courses within the centre including a Skills for Life Programme and also offers access to additional local courses inculuding; Arts and Crafts, Printmaking, Drama, Performing Arts, Music, Plastering, Room Renovations, ESOL, Literacy, Creative Writing, Numeracy, Information Technology. Service User involvement is encouraged at Ann Fowler House and there are various committees and groups including Service Users Committee, Equality & Diversity Group and Safeguarding Group.

We also have a multi faith room which can be used for quiet time and reflection.

support.supportInfo: Trained staff adopt a person centred approach and enable service users to identify and address their needs in order to move forward successfully. This is undertaken through encouragement, activities and regular support meetings, where service users are able to address their wellbeing, self esteem, spirituality, addictions and mental health in a safe environment.

name: Andrew House
synopsis: Andrew House is for single males and females who do not have access to settled accommodation and are above the age of 16.
description:
We also offer a complex needs service if you are 18+ and meet our criteria. Please see below for further details.

Some of our single rooms have ensuite bathrooms and some have shared communal bathroom facilities. Each bedroom is fully furnished and includes a flat screen TV, worktop, fridge and kettle. 

There are no ground floor rooms and each floor is accessible by stairs only.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via Liverpool MainStay - http://www.mainstayliverpool.org.uk

features.additionalFeatures:
We have a full time qualified trainer who is actively engaged in the delivery of in-house training events such as the ‘Trusted Tenants’ award. In addition we procure the services of several external professional training organisations such as; CRISIS, Alder Training and Cisco 

Residents will have access to other training facilities at alternative NWPC projects. The activities on offer will differ depending on where the person is accommodated and all service users will be able to access activities at Liverpool YMCA Leeds Street.

support.supportInfo:
We offer a complex needs service if you are 18+ and meet the following criteria: all homeless prevention options have been explored and exhausted; you have no immediate access to settled accommodation / are roofless; you have been assessed as having High Needs or exhibiting high risk in 3 out of 4 of the following areas: mental health / rough sleeping / homelessness / substance misuse /offending / have personal and social care needs that can be met by a package of up to 2 hours personal care activities per day.

Residents will be allocated a Support Worker who will facilitate formal weekly key working sessions with the resident. We will also allocate a Secondary Support Worker who will provide support for them if their Support Worker is unavailable. All residents are required to engage with the Support Services as part of their license agreement.

name: Amadudu
synopsis: A refuge for women and children fleeing Domestic Violence, prioritising the needs of Black women and children.
description: Amadudu provides independent living apartments (temporary accommodation) within the refuge building for 6 women and their children. We have 3- and 2-bedroom apartments to cater for women with larger numbers of children from babies to aged 18 years, and provide adaptable space for single women, however we do prioritise women and children.

name: All Night Cafe
synopsis: We offer a warm welcome, a hot meal and a safe place to sleep for Reading&#39;s Homeless.
description:
**COVID UPDATE**

Due to the pandemic, the All Night Cafe is closed this winter - alternative self-contained provisions are in place from central government funding.
______________________________________________


**December 2019 UPDATE** we are open every night in December 2019 thanks to additional funding from the government.

Our All Night Cafe ran overnight Friday and Saturday during the months of November and December 2018. The All Night Cafe re opened in April 2019 when the Reading winter night shelter finished. 

We welcome up to 15 homeless guests, all of whom were very grateful for the service. We offer a hot meal and safe to sleep for the night and breakfast in the morning.
We are currently recruiting more volunteers in order to offer food and shelter for 7 days a week. 

Currently we are opened:
* Fridays 9pm - 8.30am on Saturday
* Saturdays 9pm -8.30am on Sunday

To quote the words of our first guest in the All Night Cafe, 'thank you for creating a sanctuary for us.'

name: Aigburth Drive - Male Harm Reduction Service
synopsis: Hostel accommodation for single homeless men aged 40 and above who need support to manage their alcohol use.
description:
Hostel accommodation for single homeless men aged 40 and above. 

Aigburth Drive is a Harm Reduction Service for men who need support to manage their alcohol use.  The service recognises that some people who use alcohol may not be ready to stop using and become abstinent.  Our focus is on reducing the negative consequences of alcohol use rather than on eliminating (although abstinence may remain the ideal goal).

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals can be made by completing the referral form [here](https://www.whitechapelcentre.co.uk/uploads/7/6/0/9/7609171/aigburth_drive_referral_form_5_amended.docx) or by calling **0151 347 7847**.

support.supportInfo:
Each resident has a key-worker who agrees a plan with them and supports the service user to better manage the risk of harm associated with use and work towards being ready to live independently in their own accommodation.

The Service is provided jointly between the Whitechapel Centre and SHAP Ltd.
​

name: Abbott Lodge
synopsis: Accommodation for homeless people.
description: A recent development of self catering en suite rooms and self-contained apartments providing temporary accommodation and support to homeless people.

accommodation.referralNotes: The properties here are allocated through Salford City Council's housing register. To register your interest, please make contact with Salford City Council.

name: 90 Hope Street
synopsis: 90 Hope Street is our direct access homeless hostel open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. If we have a vacancy, we can offer immediate housing.
description:
90 Hope Street provides temporary accommodation in a safe and secure environment. We help you to work through the issues related to your homelessness and help you to find more permanent housing. We can help you if:
* You are aged 18 or over and
* Are sleeping rough or
* Are homeless

We can provide you with a room of your own, shared bathroom facilities and three meals a day. There is a service charge payable by you – if this is not paid regularly your bed space could be at risk. With your support worker, you will design your own action plan based on what you want to achieve. This could include:
* Support in finding permanent accommodation
* Substance misuse
* Mental health issues
* Benefits advice
* Offending behaviour
* Physical health
* Signposting to other organisations that can help

Your support worker will meet regularly with you to make sure that the help you are getting is right for you.

contact.name: 90 Hope Street
contact.telephone: Call 90 Hope Street on 01782 279234 . If you are sleeping rough, call the Rough Sleeper Team on 0800 970 2304

accommodation.referralNotes: There is a service charge payable by you – if this is not paid regularly your bed space could be at risk. With your support worker, you will design your own action plan based on what you want to achieve.

name: 85 London Road
synopsis: Single homeless men with support needs, including those with alcohol, drug or mental health problems who have some existing support. Priority given to those with a local connection to Luton.
description:
* 2 full time and 2 part time staff on-site 7.30am-9.30pm, waking night cover 9pm-8am. At weekends 1 member of staff covers 5 hostels. 
* Keywork system, 4 residents per keyworker, weekly meetings. 
* Action plans with agreed outcomes, reviewed at least quarterly. 
* Staff provide support around independent living skills, budgeting and benefits, health, social activities, community links and access to education, training and employment (paid or voluntary).

accommodation.referralNotes:
Accept self-referrals and referrals from any agency.

Call in, phone Mon-Fri 9am-5pm or write for an application form, completed by the applicant (and referral agency if applicable). Interview, needs and risk assessment. Require proof of ID for eligibility for benefits, eg NI card, passport.

name: 106 Project
synopsis: Single homeless women with support needs. Local connection required.
description:
* 1 full time and 1 part-time staff, waking night cover. 
* Keywork system with meetings held weekly. 
* Support plans reviewed monthly. 
* Staff offer advice and support with independent living skills, health issues, liaising with specialist support agencies, accessing education and training and social activities.

accommodation.referralNotes: Accept self-referrals and referrals from any agency. Many referrals come from Social Services, Luton Borough Council, short stay hostels and drug and alcohol agencies.

name: 100 Derby Road
synopsis: Temporary Accomodation to young people
description:
100 Derby Road offers temporary accommodation to young people aged 16-24 who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.

The scheme provides supported accommodation, access to a range of education, training and employment opportunities and community health services to enable young people to take the next steps towards independent living. The scheme was purpose-built in 2006.

contact.name: 100 Derby Road
contact.additionalInfo: The scheme provides supported accommodation, access to a range of education, training and employment opportunities and community health services to enable young people to take the next steps towards independent living. The scheme was purpose-built in 2006.

features.additionalFeatures: There are 12 furnished rooms with shower rooms, toilets, spacious communal TV lounge, laundry room, communal kitchen and garden. The building is secured and offers free WiFi.

support.supportInfo:
Each resident is allocated a support worker, who will work with the resident to find out what their long-term goals are, and how they can achieve them. The scheme works closely with careers services and training agencies. 

Staff are on-site as follows:

    10am – 6pm Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday
    12noon – 8pm Wednesday

There is a night service from 10pm to 6am Monday to Sunday, and an out of hours emergency service.

name: 10 Southampton Street Intensive hostel
synopsis: A 24 hour staffed hostel for homeless people in Southampton, with single rooms for men and women.

accommodation.referralNotes: Referrals via the City Council homelessness panel
